Now, we've been more successful, because our space probes have in fact reached mars with a certain amount of regularity, but there's dangers. There's radiation, there's weightlessness, micro meteorite impact, plus Mars itself is a frozen desert. You can't live off the land. There's no vegetation, no food, no water, no air.

[16:45:00] LAKE: And yet it continues to fascinate us. What makes so many people believe that life can be sustained or a colony can be sustained on Mars? What is that has put that into so many minds and imaginations.

KAKU: You know, it's part of our psyche to look for other civilizations, other worlds in outer space. Mars is the closest in terms of looking like the earth. It's a rocky planet, not a gas giant like Jupiter. The temperatures are cold, but not super-hot like Venus, and it is reachable, with a two-year mission, so it's fascinating to believe that perhaps there could be men from mars.

Well, now we know we can't even find microbial life on mars, but still it beckons. Elon Musk has said we should by a multi-planet species, so in other words we need earth 2.0. It's simply too dangerous to put homo sapiens on just one planet --

LAKE: We're doing such a good job taking care of the one we're on, we should go to others, I suppose. But truthfully a lot of people believe that if we don't do that so many things can be learned and can benefit life here, even in the quest, even if it is further out than 2030.

KAKU: Take a look at the space program. That has given us miniaturized transistors, the internet, the space program with weather satellites, telecommunications. All of that is a byproduct of the space program.

LAKE: Sorry to interrupt, do the technological advances we see help us more in space? You know, we all wonder at the leaps and bounds that we have seen, carrying smartphones around. Is that helping us make further progress into getting further into deep space.

KAKU: There is a synergy. The space program forces us to miniaturize electronic components and that gave birth to the electronic revolution, which in turn makes possible space probes that can go safely to the planets. That creates another synergy. There's a back and forth between the space program and innovation and ingenuity.

LAKE: You mentioned what a long and dangerous journey it is. What is the next generation of astronaut going to have to be like if they're going to go to Mars?

KAKU: Forget the moon. The moon was a Sunday picnic. Three days to moon, three days to come back, you can do it in a week. Mars is a nine-month mission to mars, plus you have to be on the red planet, plus another nine months going back, and realize that the world's record for being up in outer space is just a little bit over a year. That's the world's record.

LAKE: We have a way to go.

KAKU: Yes, we've got a way to go.

LAKE: Do you think the private partner-government relationship is good for everyone?

KAKU: I think it will be key. The taxpayers are saying who will foot the bill? Private enterprise wants a piece of action. They see a lot of spin offs and benefits, so I think there's a synergy between the government and taxpayer who will foot most of the bill and private enterprise because they want a piece of the action.

LAKE: Together we can get there, we think. Thank you for coming in.

KAKU: My pleasure.

LAKE: Appreciate it.

Still ahead, creepy clown sightings are no laughing matter. Next we hear from a professional about how his classic entertainment form is suffering.

[16:50:00] (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

LAKE: One of the America's most recognizable pop culture icons has fallen victim to a bizarre trend. Appearances by McDonald's mascot Ronald McDonald are being limited until the creepy pranks die down. The sinister craze these people dressing up as clowns just to scare others is a trend spreading internationally. Clare Sebastian has more from London.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GEORGE BURKE, VICTIM OF CREEPY CLOWN SIGHTING: I want to get past. I want to go out.

CLARE SEBASTIAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: This is the moment that George Burke back from Plymouth realized the clown standing in his path with what he said looked like a hammer was no joke.

BURKE: Going in, yes, off, mate.

SEBASTIAN: Clown sightings like this across the U.K. have been appearing on social media. This was on a university campus in London, a 19-year-old man was later arrested suspected of a public order offense. This was just outside London, a clown staring into a restaurant where Leah Woodcock was having dinner.

LEAH WOODCOCK, CREEPY CLOWN OBSERVER: It had like big teeth and blood and stuff. It wasn't particularly nice to see. I don't think that they're doing it just for fun. I think they're doing it to scare people. SEBASTIAN: The craze actually began in the U.S. over the summer, sightings of clowns carrying weapons and an armed robbery at a drugstore in Michigan caught on CCTV, and clown-based threats led to several school districts being put on alert. That trend now spreading to the U.K. We saw as increased police presence after an Instagram post -- for those who see themselves as good clowns the craze is particularly distressing.

Matte, the Clown, now in his 60s has been doing this for 40 years.

MATTE, THE CLOWN: Hello. I'm doing and interview. The clown can do all sorts of things. Which are really funny in the right circumstance, but with a scary mask on, very unfunny. Don't do it, please, don't do it. Dress up as something else.

UNIDENTIFIED SINGER: Clowns to the left of me, jokers to the right --

SEBASTIAN: Unfortunately, it's the right time of year for dressing up. Police have warned these incidents could increase in the run up to Halloween. Clare Sebastian, CNN, London.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

LAKE: Now, clowning is a centuries-old tradition that continues to influence modern-day film and theater. Let's speak to one of the professionals. Many know him as Kooky Cosmo, the clown, friends and colleagues call him Michael Kramer.

Michael, thank you for being here with us today.

MICHAEL KRAMER, KOOKY COSMO, THE CLOWN: Thank you for having me.

LAKE: I want to ask you, in all seriousness -- because this is quite serious -- how has this impacted your business? Have you felt any negative reaction to this craze that's going around?

KOOKY COSMO: I feel it every day. I was in the supermarket in my clown outfit. Some actually reported me to the manager and said there's a clown, and the manager had to say we know this guy, he's really nice. I hear it all the time now.

LAKE: Are you worried what that will do to your business?

KOOKY COSMO: Yes, I am worried. When I'm doing street market events, people make comments, and my clients hear that. They may get the idea that clowns are creepy now, and may not want to use us.

LAKE: Have you seen any cancellations yet?

KOOKY COSMO: I haven't, no. I'm fortunate that I have steady clients. They know me.

LAKE: Yes. Why do you think this is happening? Have you ever experienced anything like this before?

KOOKY COSMO: I've experienced negative comments about me, but that's been mainly from the movie "It", John Wayne Gacy, the serial killer they give clowns a bad name. I've heard "I hate clowns" a lot.

LAKE: But those are individuals. There have always been people who find clowns a little odd. There's always a kid at a birthday party who is not that thrilled, but obviously there are a lot of joyful moments as well. They seem to be able to coexist. All of a sudden there seems to be such a sinister connection. Do you worry it will be hard to dispel that?

KOOKY COSMO: No, I think it will die out.

LAKE: What makes you so confident?

KOOKY COSMO: I just think it will. That's how things are. People want attention at times. They just do it for attention, and then something else comes along. That will start being a big thing. I think this will die out.

LAKE: I know you have associations and memberships where all of you and your colleagues get together and communicate.

[16:55:00] Have you talked about trying to counter it or support each other or put a different message out there?

KOOKY COSMO: Find a new job? I don't know. Yes, no, we haven't spoken about it. For me what I try to do, I try to be extra nice to people and be as giving as possible, which I have always done, but now I try to be a little extra, do a little extra now.

LAKE: It's extraordinary that it's had to come to this. Are you worried about your personal safety? Usually, I'm sure when you put the outfit and you get ready to go to work, you have to get all your enthusiasm and good cheer up. Do you worry a bit about moving around now, commuting, getting to your job based on the negative reaction? The fear people seem to have?

KOOKY COSMO: I do. I travel around the New York city subway system in my clown suit. People give me looks. I am concerned that -- I don't know what they'll do. So far nothing has happened.

LAKE: We certainly know you're not one of those clowns for sure. And there are so many double entendre here but we do hope that this passes, we are all scratching our head about it. But I am sure it has been around for so long that certainly it is an art that will endure.

KOOKY COSMOS: Thank you very much

LAKE: Thank you, Michael for coming on. Have a good day.

KOOKY COSMO: you're very welcome, it's a pleasure.

LAKE: Now if you have a daily digest of the day's top business stories delivered to your inbox, you can subscribe to the QUEST MEANS BUSINESS newsletter featuring Richard's Profitable Moment and all the top headlines from the rest of the CNNMoney team.

Just go to CNNMoney.com/quest to subscribe and don't forget to download the new CNNMoney stream app, you can find that link on the CNNMoney home page.

Just time for a quick reminder of how U.S. markets ended the day. The Dow managed to hold its nerve after Tuesday's 200-point drop. The Dow closed slightly higher, up just 15 points. In the pass few hours, the Fed released its minutes from the last meeting saying the rate hike is needed "relatively soon", but there's no firm agreement on timing.

That is QUEST MEANS BUSINESS. Thanks for watching. The news continues here on CNN.

urn:contentItem:5KJG-M551-JCMN-Y09V-00000-00Clinton's Pay-to-Play Is the Natural Consequence of Big Government2016-08-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:52ZLexisNexisClinton's Pay-to-Play Is the Natural Consequence of Big GovernmentMises Institute

Aug 26, 2016( Western Free Press: http://www.westernfreepress.com/ Delivered by Newstex) ;; TagsA A Home[1] | Feed | Blog.rssThe Entrepreneur[2]Taxes and Spending[3]Entrepreneurship[4]Interventionism[5] Clinton's Pay-to-Play Is the Natural Consequence of Big Government   https://mises.org/blog/clintons-pay-play-natural-consequence-big-government0 ViewsHillary Clinton has been taking heat for her relationship with the Clinton Foundation. Did individuals and firms making large donations to the Foundation, or paying large speaking or consulting fees to Bill Clinton, get preferred access to Ms. Clinton as Secretary of State? Is there a revolving door between the Clinton campaign and the Foundation's fundraising staff? Are these relationships the subject of the emails she deleted from her private server?

These questions point to a more basic issue about the role of money in politics. What, exactly, do large corporations get in exchange for their campaign contributions? Ms. Clinton gave 92 speeches between 2013 and 2015 that netted her $21.6 million, including $1.8 million for just 8 speeches to large banks. (CNN provides eye-opening details[6] about her speaking requirements — the $225,000 fee is just the tip of the iceberg.) Ms. Clinton is hardly known for her business acumen; her infamous cattle-futures trades[7] are widely recognized as a political payoff, and her views on corporate governance[8] have been ridiculed by experts. Her opinions on world politics are already in the public domain, so I doubt that Goldman Sachs was getting $200K worth of unique insight into global affairs. Bill Clinton, with zero experience in higher-education administration, bagged $17 million[9] to be honorary chancellor of an obscure for-profit university. Why are these companies throwing their money away? Most people assume that campaign contributions, speaking and consulting fees and lucrative board positions for former and future politicians, and similar payments are pure graft, the kinds of pay-to-play arrangements common under crony capitalism. And some of these transfers surely do buy access and even specific policy outcomes. There are several problems with the common assumption, however. First, research on campaign contributions finds that the expected rate of return on these payments is quite high and yet, given the potential gains, the contribution amounts are remarkably small[10]. Second, there is little systematic evidence[11] that policies are, on average, greatly influenced by such contributions, leading some to suggest that this form of payment to politicians and political parties is mainly consumption, not investment.Lobbying as a Defensive Strategy A more intriguing finding, however, is that most large companies not only give generously, but about equally to both major parties[12], even when the parties' candidates and representatives differ on particular issues. This suggests that payments to politicians are best understood as a form of insurance. Money in politics provides protection against what Fred McChesney[13] has called 'rent-extraction' by government. For example, before the mid-1990s, the tech industry had a very low profile in Washington — few contributions, no DC headquarters for the big tech companies, and so on. After the Microsoft antitrust trial, this situation was completely reversed, and now tech companies are among the biggest lobbyists in the US[14]. The message was clear: you want to play ball, you pay up — or we shut you down. It's not that companies are necessarily paying for specific outcomes; rather, they are paying for the right to do business at all. As Ludwig von Mises pointed out, doing business in a world of aggressive governmental regulation is tricky. One consequence is to make firms more bureaucratic, by which Mises means less effective at responding to consumer needs in the most efficient manner.The Cost of Compliance with Government RegulationsUnder capitalism, the size, complexity, and strategy of corporations, reflects the decisions of capitalist-entrepreneurs about how best to earn profit, competing freely with each other for resources and consumer patronage. Under interventionism — what we now call crony capitalism — the situation is different. Now companies must employ large staffs of lawyers, accountants, lobbyists, public relations teams, and others who focus not on creating economic value, but on satisfying legal, tax, regulatory, and other government requirements. That large firms are filled with such non-productive employees is not, Mises writes in Human Action[15], 'a phenomenon of the unhampered market economy,' but a result of government policy. In his earlier book Bureaucracy[16], published in 1944, Mises challenges the idea that bureaucracy is a necessary consequence of firm size. 'No proﬁt-seeking enterprise, no matter how large, is liable to become bureaucratic provided the hands of its management are not tied by government interference. The trend toward bureaucratic rigidity is not inherent in the evolution of business. It is an outcome of government meddling with business.' By this Mises means that government interference impedes the entrepreneur's use of economic calculation and the attempt to use prices to impose managerial discipline. Mises gives three examples: taxes and price regulations that interfere with corporate proﬁts (distorting an important signal of employee performance); laws that interfere with hiring and promotion (including the need to hire people to deal with government); and the omnipresent threat of arbitrary antitrust or regulatory activity, in response to which entrepreneurs must become adept at 'diplomacy and bribery.' This is why large companies send millions of dollars to the Clintons and other top politicians in both major parties. A President Hillary Clinton could direct billions to favored companies, and take billions of potential profits away from those that don't 'play the game.' Just as journalists know that tough questions will get them banned from future press conferences, business leaders under crony capitalism know that if they don't contribute, don't hire, don't pay the right people in Washington or Brussels or wherever, they won't be successful. The solution? Take away the ability of government to intervene in economic affairs. Just imagine the popularity of Ms. Clinton on the speaking circuit in a world like that! Peter G. Klein[17] is Carl Menger Research Fellow of the Mises Institute; Professor of Entrepreneurship at Baylor University's Hankamer School of Business;Senior Research Fellow with Baylor's Baugh Center for Entrepreneurship and Free Enterprise; and Adjunct Professor of Strategy and Management at the Norwegian School of Economics. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5KJG-NR91-DXKX-027M-00000-00Clinton's Pay-to-Play Is the Natural Consequence of Big Government2016-08-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:52ZLexisNexisClinton's Pay-to-Play Is the Natural Consequence of Big Government

Aug 26, 2016( Western Free Press: http://www.westernfreepress.com/Delivered by Newstex) ;; TagsA A Home[1] | Feed | Blog.rssThe Entrepreneur[2]Taxes and Spending[3]Entrepreneurship[4]Interventionism[5] Clinton's Pay-to-Play Is the Natural Consequence of Big Government   https://mises.org/blog/clintons-pay-play-natural-consequence-big-government0 ViewsHillary Clinton has been taking heat for her relationship with the Clinton Foundation. Did individuals and firms making large donations to the Foundation, or paying large speaking or consulting fees to Bill Clinton, get preferred access to Ms. Clinton as Secretary of State? Is there a revolving door between the Clinton campaign and the Foundation's fundraising staff? Are these relationships the subject of the emails she deleted from her private server?

These questions point to a more basic issue about the role of money in politics. What, exactly, do large corporations get in exchange for their campaign contributions? Ms. Clinton gave 92 speeches between 2013 and 2015 that netted her $21.6 million, including $1.8 million for just 8 speeches to large banks. (CNN provides eye-opening details[6] about her speaking requirements the $225,000 fee is just the tip of the iceberg.) Ms. Clinton is hardly known for her business acumen; her infamous cattle-futures trades[7] are widely recognized as a political payoff, and her views on corporate governance[8] have been ridiculed by experts. Her opinions on world politics are already in the public domain, so I doubt that Goldman Sachs was getting $200K worth of unique insight into global affairs. Bill Clinton, with zero experience in higher-education administration, bagged $17 million[9] to be honorary chancellor of an obscure for-profit university. Why are these companies throwing their money away? Most people assume that campaign contributions, speaking and consulting fees and lucrative board positions for former and future politicians, and similar payments are pure graft, the kinds of pay-to-play arrangements common under crony capitalism. And some of these transfers surely do buy access and even specific policy outcomes. There are several problems with the common assumption, however. First, research on campaign contributions finds that the expected rate of return on these payments is quite high and yet, given the potential gains, the contribution amounts are remarkably small[10]. Second, there is little systematic evidence[11] that policies are, on average, greatly influenced by such contributions, leading some to suggest that this form of payment to politicians and political parties is mainly consumption, not investment.Lobbying as a Defensive Strategy A more intriguing finding, however, is that most large companies not only give generously, but about equally to both major parties[12], even when the parties' candidates and representatives differ on particular issues. This suggests that payments to politicians are best understood as a form of insurance. Money in politics provides protection against what Fred McChesney[13] has called 'rent-extraction' by government. For example, before the mid-1990s, the tech industry had a very low profile in Washington few contributions, no DC headquarters for the big tech companies, and so on. After the Microsoft antitrust trial, this situation was completely reversed, and now tech companies are among the biggest lobbyists in the US[14]. The message was clear: you want to play ball, you pay up or we shut you down. It's not that companies are necessarily paying for specific outcomes; rather, they are paying for the right to do business at all. As Ludwig von Mises pointed out, doing business in a world of aggressive governmental regulation is tricky. One consequence is to make firms more bureaucratic, by which Mises means less effective at responding to consumer needs in the most efficient manner.The Cost of Compliance with Government RegulationsUnder capitalism, the size, complexity, and strategy of corporations, reflects the decisions of capitalist-entrepreneurs about how best to earn profit, competing freely with each other for resources and consumer patronage. Under interventionism what we now call crony capitalism the situation is different. Now companies must employ large staffs of lawyers, accountants, lobbyists, public relations teams, and others who focus not on creating economic value, but on satisfying legal, tax, regulatory, and other government requirements. That large firms are filled with such non-productive employees is not, Mises writes in Human Action[15], 'a phenomenon of the unhampered market economy,' but a result of government policy. In his earlier book Bureaucracy[16], published in 1944, Mises challenges the idea that bureaucracy is a necessary consequence of firm size. 'No pro t-seeking enterprise, no matter how large, is liable to become bureaucratic provided the hands of its management are not tied by government interference. The trend toward bureaucratic rigidity is not inherent in the evolution of business. It is an outcome of government meddling with business.' By this Mises means that government interference impedes the entrepreneur's use of economic calculation and the attempt to use prices to impose managerial discipline. Mises gives three examples: taxes and price regulations that interfere with corporate pro ts (distorting an important signal of employee performance); laws that interfere with hiring and promotion (including the need to hire people to deal with government); and the omnipresent threat of arbitrary antitrust or regulatory activity, in response to which entrepreneurs must become adept at 'diplomacy and bribery.' This is why large companies send millions of dollars to the Clintons and other top politicians in both major parties. A President Hillary Clinton could direct billions to favored companies, and take billions of potential profits away from those that don't 'play the game.' Just as journalists know that tough questions will get them banned from future press conferences, business leaders under crony capitalism know that if they don't contribute, don't hire, don't pay the right people in Washington or Brussels or wherever, they won't be successful. The solution? Take away the ability of government to intervene in economic affairs. Just imagine the popularity of Ms. Clinton on the speaking circuit in a world like that! Peter G. Klein[17] is Carl Menger Research Fellow of the Mises Institute; Professor of Entrepreneurship at Baylor University's Hankamer School of Business;Senior Research Fellow with Baylor's Baugh Center for Entrepreneurship and Free Enterprise; and Adjunct Professor of Strategy and Management at the Norwegian School of Economics. The trend toward bureaucratic rigidity is not inherent in the evolution of business. It is an outcome of government meddling with business.' By this Mises means that government interference impedes the entrepreneur's use of economic calculation and the attempt to use prices to impose managerial discipline. urn:contentItem:5RJ1-4MN1-JBHT-D179-00000-00Clinton Takes on Grammys; Canada And Mexico Reject NAFTA Proposal; Soldiers Killed in Kabul; Intel Chip Flaw Fallout2018-01-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:52ZLexisNexisClinton Takes on Grammys; Canada And Mexico Reject NAFTA Proposal; Soldiers Killed in Kabul; Intel Chip Flaw FalloutLanhamFULL TEXT

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN:AM: Welcome back and good morning to Maria Bartiromo.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Hey there, ladies. good morning to you. Happy Monday, everybody, thank you so much. Happy to be back in New York. Good morning and happy Monday, I am Maria Bartiromo, and it is Monday, January 29. Your top stories right now, 6 a.m. on the East Coast.

Getting tough on trade, President Trump's America First message already being tested as Mexico and Canada are rejecting a proposal by the White House to rework a key part of the North American Free Trade Agreement. This comes as a commander in chief targets Europe signaling possible payback over what he called unfair trade policies with the EU.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I've had a lot of problems with the European Union. And it may morph into something very big from that standpoint, from a trade standpoint. The European Union has treated the United States very unfairly when it comes to trade. The European Union has been very, very unfair to the United States. It will turn out to be very much to their detriment.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The president will address the trade debate assaults the United States economic boom during his first State of the Union address Tuesday night. That will be of course live, and we'll take it for you. The address comes as a major indices all close at record levels again on Friday. Take a look at Friday's performance up 223 points on the Dow, up almost 1 percent. 26,616, a new record there. S&P 500 in unchartered territory with a 33-point rally. The Nasdaq as well.

This morning a bit of a pull back from those numbers futures indicating a lower open for the broader averages we have about 25 points on the Dow, down about 18 on the Nasdaq. We are watching the yield on the benchmark 10-year treasury. It is as you can see rising, it broke 2.7 percent for the first time since early 2014 building on Friday's again after the fourth quarter GDP came out, and that was up 2.6 percent. Yields on the rise and stocks lower.

In Europe this morning, take a look at the indices, as we watch rates moving higher even if fractionally, FT 100 it is up fraction, quarter of a percent. The CAC Quarante and the DAX index all over again fractional move here.

In Asia, overnight stocks were mostly lower with the exception of Korea. As you can see there, the worst performer was China, Shanghai composite done about one percent.

Terror strikes in military school in Afghanistan. The details on the attack that left 11 dead, over a dozen injured. And is technology putting our troops in danger? The new concern this morning or free fitness app that is being used on devices like Fitbit better actually tracking our military. We will get into it.

Then Intel's morning over critical security flaws came after it first flagged the issue to several Chinese businesses including Alibaba. The news leaving the United States government with a chip on its shoulder over Intel.

Hillary Clinton using the Grammy stage to mock President Trump. The appearance that is leaving many feeling fire and fury of their own this morning. Although stories coming up this morning. And joining me to talk about it fox Business network's Dagen McDowell. PwC partner, Mitch Roschelle and Maslansky and Partners president, Lee Carter.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY AND PARTNERS: Great to see you welcome back.

BARTIROMO: Happy to be back.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CO-HOST: Welcome back. Amazing work.

BARTIROMO: Thank you, I missed you, it was a really good trip. I can't wait to get back here and talk about all the issues of the day we talk about every morning.

MCDOWELL: Everything we are fired up about. Fire and fury.

BARTIROMO: You were at the Grammys.

PWC PARTNER, MITCH ROSCHELLE: I was at the Grammys.

BARTIROMO: So, you saw all of the readings of "Fire and Fury" up close and personal.

ROSCHELLE: I did. Yes, I was rolling my eyes.

BARTIROMO: I don't know why they do that or they make an assumption everybody agrees with them.

ROSCHELLE: The crowd there definitely did base upon a response. I was actually assuming. My bet was Obama was going to be -- I knew something was going on.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes, that's a good point. I am surprised Obama wasn't there actually.

MCDOWELL: He can't run again.

CASONE: I know I think your generally classier than that.

BARTIROMO: Yes, well, Hillary Clinton their reading right from the book. And Cher as well. I will get into it, a big night at the Grammys, coming up this morning former senior advisor to the Clintons, the Stagwell Group, president and managing partner, Mark Penn is with us this morning.

Former presidential candidate, Mike Huckabee is here, and Trump for President senior advisor, Lara Trump making an appearance. Plus, a Fox News senior judicial analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. And Joy Villa was at the Grammys last night, singer and songwriter, former Trump Campaign Advisory Board member, Joy Villa.

And the COO of Lamborghini America, Alessandro Farmeschi, is joining us this morning. We've got some hot wheels on the plaza, don't miss a moment of it, that's all coming up. But first this top story this hour and that is trade, Mexico and Canada now rejecting a proposal by the Trump administration to rework the corporate arbitration system. A key part of the North American Free Trade Agreement also known as NAFTA. It comes as the president himself is speaking out an unfair trade practices with the European Union even hinting at retaliation there.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I have a lot of problems with the European Union.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You have done business with them.

TRUMP: Not a question of doing business, but I will tell you representing the United States. It is a very unfair situation. We cannot get our product in. It's very, very tough. And yet they send their product to us. No taxes, very little taxes. Very unfair. I have a lot of problems with European Union and it may morph into something very big from a trade standpoint. The European Union has treated the United States very unfairly when it came to trade.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: end of course trade expected to be one of the key elements in the present state of the union speech tomorrow night, Dagen, I guess infrastructure is the bigger headline. And he is not going to withdraw from NAFTA at the speech. But were expected from the state of the union tomorrow night?

MCDOWELL: In "The Wall Street Journal" the headline about Canada and Mexico rejecting a proposal which is kind of one of the linchpins in the renegotiation of NAFTA, about how you handle corporate arbitration.

We would prefer it that these disputes go through domestic courts but again this is one huge stumbling block. I would say that trade in any foul-up with trade with other nations around the world is one of the three biggest risks to the market in our economy in the next year. You have the 11 remaining countries in the Trans Pacific Partnership, which we withdrew from, cutting a new deal last week, it will be signed in March.

The European Union and Japan, the end of last year making giant trade deal that will reduce scrap duties on cars coming in from Japan to Europe, scrap duties on cheese and wine being imported into Japan. This is one of the great truths that we start cutting ourselves off from the rest of the world.

I know that President Trump talks about bad trade deals, but how about some trade deals. We need to also deal with NAFTA and also ink that trade deal with South Korea before we can move ahead with any other bilateral deals with nations around the world.

BARTIROMO: Yes, which is why last week, Mitch, there was some worry that there will be some more to tariffs on solar panels and tariffs on washing machines. Maybe aluminum and steel are next and little by little discrete creates a real trade issue.

ROSCHELLE: If you look at the GDP numbers that came out last week they would've been a whole percentage point higher if it wasn't for trade imbalance. Obviously, the president is very focused on trade balance and he campaigned on that, and he is pushing forward to try to make things a little bit more fear around the planet.

BARTIROMO: It's a balance low. I mean, Lee, the White House says that the tone of the president's State of the Union message tomorrow night is going to be one of bipartisanship. One very forward-looking in terms of his agenda. How much of that includes these issues over trade remains to be seen.

CARTER: I think were going to see a lot about trade, immigration, I think it's going talk about infrastructure, I think you will talk about jobs and the economy, I think he is going to spend time talking about what he is most comfortable with. What I think is going to be notably absent from the speech, healthcare. The reason for that is that is a really partisan issue right now and I think you can see the administration is making a lot of progress in some of these other negotiations with Democrats on immigration.

There was an interview last week with Chuck Schumer where he said he was willing to talk to the president about these things. Of course, they get upset when the terms change, but I think that he is really going to focus on those issues that are first and foremost in people's minds right now. But I think it's really interesting that he is not going to be talking about healthcare.

BARTIROMO: You would think infrastructure a sort of along both party lines, and that would be a positive, but there debating over the cost, right. According to a new Politico Morning Consult poll, by the way, a majority of voters want to hear the president talk about healthcare and economy. You don't think that is front and center. You have got to believe there is a lot on infrastructure though. Isn't there a lot there to talk about infrastructure?

ROSCHELLE: In theory, and we have been talking about since the election, infrastructure should be a bipartisan issue that everybody is going to get behind. But I don't think anything is bipartisan anymore.

BARTIROMO: First it was supposed to be $1 trillion deal, now we are talking about $1.7 trillion, but we should point out that the federal money is 200 billion. The number is largely expected private and public partnerships. We'll see.

MCDOWELL: It remains to be seen how those work out because public-private partnerships work if it is for say a toll road, where there is revenue generation from that project. In terms of just throwing money, I think you have 2.7 percent could hire on the 10-year yield. That is related, so watch tariffs driving up costs. Watch talk about the weakening dollar which imports inflation into this country.

I think the Trump administration, and this is a warning to them. They need to be careful of anything in terms of driving up inflation in the United States borrowing costs at this point, and also how much more money you are going to borrow after we doubled it out during the last administration. Those are very, very big concerns because President Trump love talking about the record breaking run in the stock market. The one thing that will throw cold water on it is much higher borrowing costs. And 2.7, let that be a warning.

BARTIROMO: You are right, and we already saw a come back from South Korea, LG comes out last week and says, oh, guess what we are going to raise prices. So that was as a result of the tariff.

MCDOWELL: I want to say really quickly one thing. These are companies like Samsung that have jobs in the United States. They have a new appliance plant in South Carolina. Part of these tariffs on imported parts above a certain level. If you try to import parts into this country and assemble washing machines and create jobs in the nation, the Republican Governor of South Carolina is very concerned about these tariffs.

BARTIROMO: They have to figure out a way, what's the cost because you can't keep putting a terror retirement crosses the border, because reports are coming from different places. Same issue with autos. Because the parts are coming from different places, so you have got to come up with one tariffs and not have overly done tariffs, if you will.

More to come on that. Coming up terrorism strikes a military school in Afghanistan. We have got that story, the details on the attack that left 11 people dead.

Then the dangerous discovery that is putting our soldiers at risk. A new report shows the fitness devices are exposing sensitive military locations, you've got to hear this. And then Hillary Clinton surprise appearance at the Grammys, the former presidential candidate's latest jab at the commander-in-chief. That is all ahead. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back another deadly attack in Afghanistan to report. Militants reading a military Academy in Kabul. Cheryl Casone with the details in headlines. Cheryl, good morning to you.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN:AM CO-HOST: Good morning. Maria, another attack to talk about there. At least seven soldiers have been killed, 16 others wounded. It was an early morning assault on a military compound in Kabul. The Islamic State group claiming responsibility in this comes only two days after more than 100 people were killed in a suicide attack in the afghan capital. This month alone, more than 200 people have been killed and hundreds wounded in a series of attacks unleashed by the Taliban and their rival, ISIS.

Meanwhile, this is interesting, a popular fitness app is revealing top- secret information about the location of the U.S. military bases. "The Washington Post" reports that the apps draw heatmaps, pinpoint soldier's workouts near previously undisclosed military bases, and some spy outposts. This is part of Strava GPS dealer gathering available on smart phones and yes, the Fitbit. Which a lot of soldiers wear because it's Fitbit.

And there is more fallout today from security flaws that Intel found in its chips. "The Wall Street Journal" reporting that Intel told some Chinese technology companies about the potential problems but not the U.S. government. Security experts say they may have given the Chinese government a heads up about the flaws known as inspector and meltdown. Remember those laws allow hackers to access personal data and researchers say there's no sign the information was ever exploited, shares of Intel Laura new premarket right now more than half a percent.

Apple reportedly cutting its iPhone 10 production in half in the first quarter, this is due to disappointing holiday sales in Europe, the U.S. and China. Japan's Nikkei is reporting that Apple is lowering its production targets to 20 million units. Part of the problem could be Apple's price tag which starts at $1000. Remember, guys, the stock took a hit last week as well. Shares of Apple trading slightly lower in the premarket. Almost half a percent they are reporting by the way later on in the week, guys.

And then finally this, the Grammys. Typically, it is all about music, right. Well, he got really political. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Hip-hop, real talk. That is love, baby. Jay for president.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Tonight, in this room full music dreamers, we remember this country was built by dreamers, for dreamers chasing the American dream, and all I know, it is just like dreams, these kids can't be forgotten. And are worth fighting for.

HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER SECRETARY OF STATE: We have a longtime fear of being poisoned. One reason why he like to eat at McDonald's. Nobody knew he was coming, and the food was tastily made.

(END OF VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: And we should say United States Ambassador to the UN, Nikki Haley, was not happy about this. Here's her tweet, she said I always loved the Grammys, but how artists read the "Fire and Fury" book killed it. Don't ruin great music with trash, some of us love music without the politics thrown in it.

Now back to the music, the big winner of the night was Bruno Mars, he earned the top three awards, he got album of the year for "24k Magic", and he won 6 Grammys told, singer and songwriter Joy Villa, by the way, wore a make America great again dress, remember at the Grammys last year. Well, she's coming up later on the show you new dressed that she wore last night. She is getting a lot of buzz, Maria, about her latest outfit.

BARTIROMO: Yes, her purse said choose life, enter dress was another extension of that. So, she is going to join us and talk more about that. You were the Grammys.

ROSCHELLE: I was.

BARTIROMO: Tell us about it.

ROSCHELLE: It was awesome. Bruno Mars, he was incredible. That was great. But the highlight for me was Elton John, everybody my generation was hanging on for Elton John's performance.

BARTIROMO: And he did a duo with Miley Cyrus. Right before that it's when you saw the "Fire and Fury" book readings, and that's when I turned it off, although my TV was still on and I did see it.

Once I saw the readings on "Fire and Fury", I was like, OK, that's it, I'm done. Did you watch it?

MCDOWELL: I watched some of it. This is what we expect, music is politics. A lot of these musicians there, and for the last 50 years, the music has been filled with political statements, so again that is what you're going to get. Kendrick Lamar, if he hadn't done what he did and that opening number which was incredibly powerful, the people would've been disappointed.

BARTIROMO: You know what though, Bruno Mars did not get political.

MCDOWELL: But his music isn't political. It's when a singer starts making political statements that's out of character. But U2 again, their entire career has been tinged with making political statements.

BARTIROMO: Going into the show, Jay Z it's all about negatives about President Trump. The president actually fought back at them on Twitter.

CARTER: I think it is interesting now that the new elites are in Grammys, are in music or entertainment, in the are completely out of touch with the American public. In it continues.

MCDOWELL: Would they have been able to rally votes, Hillary would have won.

CARTER: That's right.

MCDOWELL: If all the people who listen to their music would have gone out there and voted, she might have won.

BARTIROMO: That's right, they didn't come out. All right, we will take a break, when we come back market momentum rages, the Dow, the Nasdaq, the S&P 500 trading at record highs even we're looking at a fractional pullback this morning. What if anything slows things down for going let take a look at that, the risks. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BENIN VIDEO CLIP)

DAVID BURROUGHS, MECUM AUCTIONS AUTOMOBILE AUTHENTICATION EXPERT: It's about the size of the tip of a ballpoint pen.

JAMIE COLBY, FBN HOST: David Burroughs, Mecum Auctions automobile authentication expert, pinpoints the problem for me.

BURROUGHS: So, if you count in 13 of these ribs would be right about in the center of this little gutter.

COLBY: But it's missing.

BURROUGHS: So restored cars could get all sanded off to make it pretty and shiny, and found that little fingerprint gets obliterated, so that implies that this car has either been restored or at least something is fishy.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: That was a clip from tonight's all new "Strange Inheritance" on Fox Business Network host Jamie Colby set out for Chicago to meet the son of a Vietnam vet was left in mint condition Corvette, in joining us right now, the host of "Strange Inheritance," Jamie Colby. Jamie, what a great story, tell us about this.

COLBY: What a cliffhanger that was.

BARTIROMO: 1967 Corvette Stingray.

COLBY: And they have a little dimple under the hood that was part of the original mold. This car, it was missing. With the son of this Vietnam veteran who sent his combat pay home to give him an incentive to come out alive and make it back, he treated this as well as his five children. In the son inherited it and realized he could not divided into three, for his kids when he passed, so he finally decides to sell it. But he only wanted to go to a family that will appreciate story behind it about his father.

And Mecum Auctions actually did propose that this car was special, not only it sold $675,000 but it had incredible military story behind it, and what an honor for me to pay tribute to our troops by telling the story of this Vietnam veteran tonight. But that little divot missing. It is an authentication issue.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

COLBY: You have to watch to find out.

BARTIROMO: We will. It's a great story. All of these stories are so fascinating, I want to take a clip of the second episode airing at 9:30 eastern tonight. What's this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHARLOTTE SMITH, COLLECTOR OF CLOTHES: I just lost my job. And I thought I am actually a two homeowner because my collection actually cost me more than maintaining my house.

COLBY: Charlotte can only afford to keep one.

SMITH: It was awful, but you know what I just thought there is no way I would inherit a collection like this for no reason. I made the decision I'd rather sell my house than my collection.

COLBY: Now, think about that. First addresses cost her, her shop, next the cost her, her husband, now for cost her, her house.

(END OF VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: She's giving everything up except the clothes.

COLBY: Here's the amazing thing and we are learning a lot from viewers writing us, her godmother was a Quaker. The last fashionista that you would imagine. She got $25 from her parents and bought her first dress, in turn it was out of control.

3000 dresses that were left to Charlotte Smith who was an antique shop owner in Australia, and she has one of the most significant and historic fashion collections. Her husband said, it's me or the clothes, babe. And she said. Bye bye.

And she has made a career, she said this is not just a collection, it is a calling. She has written a book on Dior, she has written a book on Chanel, the collection is priceless we saw it here in New York at Parsons. And wait until you see what she's done with it, but a Quaker very unlikely, but a great story of her and Matt, also the first gentleman who inherited the Corvette wanted to do the right thing. Twists and turns tonight, Maria. If you watch one night of "Strange Inheritance" this season, this is it.

BARTIROMO: I'll be watching. Jamie, great show. Congrats.

COLBY: Thank you, Maria, great to see you, don't forget that money collection you have, the coins and the dollars. I'm waiting.

BARTIROMO: I collect currency. One of these days I'm going to bring it in and show everybody. Thank you so much, Jamie Colby there. Check out "Strange Inheritance" tonight.

We had a great week last week, if you missed it, here are some of the top moments from our program live from the World Economic Forum last week in Davos, Switzerland.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: In Davos, welcome to this morning's panel.

BRIAN MOYNIHAN, CEO, BANK OF AMERICA: 2018 it is going to be a little bit about United States trying to make itself a bit more competitive, as that changes the dynamic is going to reverberate a little bit in the world. And so, there is an attitude are you here from the administration about free trade policy has to be fair trade, but that has to settle back to the real question how do you get those imbalances straightened out.

TIDJANE THIAM, CEO, CREDIT SUISSE: We have already portrayed recently because actually investors in Europe trade grew more slowly than world GDP. Which was very worrying. But I remain optimistic, I think we are in an exceptionally favorable context.

BARTIROMO: You said that there have always been trade wars, were you suggesting that the United States is engaging somewhat in a trade war or this is just the way the people look at it?

WILBUR ROSS, COMMERCE SECRETARY OF THE UNITED STATES: What I meant was this, every time someone violates trade rules that to me is an act of war. Things are changing, I think they know we are not going to be suckers anymore.

STEPHEN SCHWARZMAN, CEO, THE BLACKSTONE GROUP: Countries outside the United States are recognizing that the United States competitive posture has changed quite dramatically. And we are going to be seeing on anticipated foreign investment into the United States because we will be the best of developed market in the world.

BARTIROMO: Were you surprised at all to get all of this focus and questions hammered about your comments that are weaker dollar is good for trade.

STEVEN MNUCHIN, TREASURY SECRETARY OF THE UNITED STATES: Again, I am a bit surprises because my comments on the dollar has been completely consistent going back for a number of years. The Treasury Secretary has just kind of commented on strong dollar, strong dollar, strong dollar. And again, my perspective is there is a free market, where it is a short-term is not a concern of ours.

ELAINE CHAO, TRANSPORTATION SECRETARY: The transformative nature of technology in transportation is very exciting. But it also cautions us to address issues about safety, security, accessibility and also privacy.

BARTIROMO: How soon before we see driverless cars on the road as the norm?

CHAO: I think it will come not as fast as some people say, but sooner than many expect.

GINNI ROMETTY, CEO, IBM: I wish it wasn't called artificial intelligence, Augmented intelligence. That it is really going to propel the world forward. I think this is a really important inflection point in time for companies but for the tech industry, society at large. This idea that it is our job to steward in these new technologies and guide them safely into the world.

BARTIROMO: I've got to get your take on the employment situation right now. Because there is this whole debate about DACA.

BILL GATES, FOUNDER, MICROSOFT: We got the country and immigrants. We are very lucky country where lots of highly energetic and talented people want to come to our country. I certainly believe that we should all want them to stay and contribute. We could get the Dreamers, solve them, we could look at immigration more broadly.

KIRSTJEN NIELSEN, HOMELAND SECURITY SECRETARY: America first is not America alone. We need a partner. You know, as I've said earlier, not one of us has the ability to do this alone. So we need to partner with private sector, we need to partner with our allies.

RANIA AL ABDULLAH, QUEEN CONSORT OF JORDAN: America being great again, it comes from America engaging with the rest of the world and sharing its -- the principles that it represents. I'm looking forward to seeing how the United States will continue to set the -- to be the moral authority and leader in the world.

RICK PERRY, SECRETARY, U.S. ENERGY: You have to understand what America first means to the president of the administration and it's really pretty simple from my perspective. This is about America being competitive around the globe when folks are thinking about where you want to buy your energy from, where do you want that next load of L&G to come from. We want you to think about America, first.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back, good Monday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, it is Monday, January 29th, your top stories right now 6:30 on the East Coast.

One day away, President Trump's first State of the Union Address, this Tuesday night, he's expected to bring up the booming economy, the soaring market and an infrastructure plan. We will have full coverage, live, from our nation's capital, tomorrow and Wednesday, right here.

urn:contentItem:5RJ1-4MN1-JBHT-D16Y-00000-00Clinton Takes on Grammys; Canada And Mexico Reject NAFTA Proposal; Soldiers Killed in Kabul; Intel Chip Flaw Fallout2018-01-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:52ZLexisNexisClinton Takes on Grammys; Canada And Mexico Reject NAFTA Proposal; Soldiers Killed in Kabul; Intel Chip Flaw FalloutLanhamFULL TEXT

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN:AM: Welcome back and good morning to Maria Bartiromo.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Hey there, ladies. good morning to you. Happy Monday, everybody, thank you so much. Happy to be back in New York. Good morning and happy Monday, I am Maria Bartiromo, and it is Monday, January 29. Your top stories right now, 6 a.m. on the East Coast.

Getting tough on trade, President Trump's America First message already being tested as Mexico and Canada are rejecting a proposal by the White House to rework a key part of the North American Free Trade Agreement. This comes as a commander in chief targets Europe signaling possible payback over what he called unfair trade policies with the EU.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I've had a lot of problems with the European Union. And it may morph into something very big from that standpoint, from a trade standpoint. The European Union has treated the United States very unfairly when it comes to trade. The European Union has been very, very unfair to the United States. It will turn out to be very much to their detriment.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The president will address the trade debate assaults the United States economic boom during his first State of the Union address Tuesday night. That will be of course live, and we'll take it for you. The address comes as a major indices all close at record levels again on Friday. Take a look at Friday's performance up 223 points on the Dow, up almost 1 percent. 26,616, a new record there. S&P 500 in unchartered territory with a 33-point rally. The Nasdaq as well.

This morning a bit of a pull back from those numbers futures indicating a lower open for the broader averages we have about 25 points on the Dow, down about 18 on the Nasdaq. We are watching the yield on the benchmark 10-year treasury. It is as you can see rising, it broke 2.7 percent for the first time since early 2014 building on Friday's again after the fourth quarter GDP came out, and that was up 2.6 percent. Yields on the rise and stocks lower.

In Europe this morning, take a look at the indices, as we watch rates moving higher even if fractionally, FT 100 it is up fraction, quarter of a percent. The CAC Quarante and the DAX index all over again fractional move here.

In Asia, overnight stocks were mostly lower with the exception of Korea. As you can see there, the worst performer was China, Shanghai composite done about one percent.

Terror strikes in military school in Afghanistan. The details on the attack that left 11 dead, over a dozen injured. And is technology putting our troops in danger? The new concern this morning or free fitness app that is being used on devices like Fitbit better actually tracking our military. We will get into it.

Then Intel's morning over critical security flaws came after it first flagged the issue to several Chinese businesses including Alibaba. The news leaving the United States government with a chip on its shoulder over Intel.

Hillary Clinton using the Grammy stage to mock President Trump. The appearance that is leaving many feeling fire and fury of their own this morning. Although stories coming up this morning. And joining me to talk about it fox Business network's Dagen McDowell. PwC partner, Mitch Roschelle and Maslansky and Partners president, Lee Carter.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY AND PARTNERS: Great to see you welcome back.

BARTIROMO: Happy to be back.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CO-HOST: Welcome back. Amazing work.

BARTIROMO: Thank you, I missed you, it was a really good trip. I can't wait to get back here and talk about all the issues of the day we talk about every morning.

MCDOWELL: Everything we are fired up about. Fire and fury.

BARTIROMO: You were at the Grammys.

PWC PARTNER, MITCH ROSCHELLE: I was at the Grammys.

BARTIROMO: So, you saw all of the readings of "Fire and Fury" up close and personal.

ROSCHELLE: I did. Yes, I was rolling my eyes.

BARTIROMO: I don't know why they do that or they make an assumption everybody agrees with them.

ROSCHELLE: The crowd there definitely did base upon a response. I was actually assuming. My bet was Obama was going to be -- I knew something was going on.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes, that's a good point. I am surprised Obama wasn't there actually.

MCDOWELL: He can't run again.

CASONE: I know I think your generally classier than that.

BARTIROMO: Yes, well, Hillary Clinton their reading right from the book. And Cher as well. I will get into it, a big night at the Grammys, coming up this morning former senior advisor to the Clintons, the Stagwell Group, president and managing partner, Mark Penn is with us this morning.

Former presidential candidate, Mike Huckabee is here, and Trump for President senior advisor, Lara Trump making an appearance. Plus, a Fox News senior judicial analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano. And Joy Villa was at the Grammys last night, singer and songwriter, former Trump Campaign Advisory Board member, Joy Villa.

And the COO of Lamborghini America, Alessandro Farmeschi, is joining us this morning. We've got some hot wheels on the plaza, don't miss a moment of it, that's all coming up. But first this top story this hour and that is trade, Mexico and Canada now rejecting a proposal by the Trump administration to rework the corporate arbitration system. A key part of the North American Free Trade Agreement also known as NAFTA. It comes as the president himself is speaking out an unfair trade practices with the European Union even hinting at retaliation there.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I have a lot of problems with the European Union.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You have done business with them.

TRUMP: Not a question of doing business, but I will tell you representing the United States. It is a very unfair situation. We cannot get our product in. It's very, very tough. And yet they send their product to us. No taxes, very little taxes. Very unfair. I have a lot of problems with European Union and it may morph into something very big from a trade standpoint. The European Union has treated the United States very unfairly when it came to trade.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: end of course trade expected to be one of the key elements in the present state of the union speech tomorrow night, Dagen, I guess infrastructure is the bigger headline. And he is not going to withdraw from NAFTA at the speech. But were expected from the state of the union tomorrow night?

MCDOWELL: In "The Wall Street Journal" the headline about Canada and Mexico rejecting a proposal which is kind of one of the linchpins in the renegotiation of NAFTA, about how you handle corporate arbitration.

We would prefer it that these disputes go through domestic courts but again this is one huge stumbling block. I would say that trade in any foul-up with trade with other nations around the world is one of the three biggest risks to the market in our economy in the next year. You have the 11 remaining countries in the Trans Pacific Partnership, which we withdrew from, cutting a new deal last week, it will be signed in March.

The European Union and Japan, the end of last year making giant trade deal that will reduce scrap duties on cars coming in from Japan to Europe, scrap duties on cheese and wine being imported into Japan. This is one of the great truths that we start cutting ourselves off from the rest of the world.

I know that President Trump talks about bad trade deals, but how about some trade deals. We need to also deal with NAFTA and also ink that trade deal with South Korea before we can move ahead with any other bilateral deals with nations around the world.

BARTIROMO: Yes, which is why last week, Mitch, there was some worry that there will be some more to tariffs on solar panels and tariffs on washing machines. Maybe aluminum and steel are next and little by little discrete creates a real trade issue.

ROSCHELLE: If you look at the GDP numbers that came out last week they would've been a whole percentage point higher if it wasn't for trade imbalance. Obviously, the president is very focused on trade balance and he campaigned on that, and he is pushing forward to try to make things a little bit more fear around the planet.

BARTIROMO: It's a balance low. I mean, Lee, the White House says that the tone of the president's State of the Union message tomorrow night is going to be one of bipartisanship. One very forward-looking in terms of his agenda. How much of that includes these issues over trade remains to be seen.

CARTER: I think were going to see a lot about trade, immigration, I think it's going talk about infrastructure, I think you will talk about jobs and the economy, I think he is going to spend time talking about what he is most comfortable with. What I think is going to be notably absent from the speech, healthcare. The reason for that is that is a really partisan issue right now and I think you can see the administration is making a lot of progress in some of these other negotiations with Democrats on immigration.

There was an interview last week with Chuck Schumer where he said he was willing to talk to the president about these things. Of course, they get upset when the terms change, but I think that he is really going to focus on those issues that are first and foremost in people's minds right now. But I think it's really interesting that he is not going to be talking about healthcare.

BARTIROMO: You would think infrastructure a sort of along both party lines, and that would be a positive, but there debating over the cost, right. According to a new Politico Morning Consult poll, by the way, a majority of voters want to hear the president talk about healthcare and economy. You don't think that is front and center. You have got to believe there is a lot on infrastructure though. Isn't there a lot there to talk about infrastructure?

ROSCHELLE: In theory, and we have been talking about since the election, infrastructure should be a bipartisan issue that everybody is going to get behind. But I don't think anything is bipartisan anymore.

BARTIROMO: First it was supposed to be $1 trillion deal, now we are talking about $1.7 trillion, but we should point out that the federal money is 200 billion. The number is largely expected private and public partnerships. We'll see.

MCDOWELL: It remains to be seen how those work out because public-private partnerships work if it is for say a toll road, where there is revenue generation from that project. In terms of just throwing money, I think you have 2.7 percent could hire on the 10-year yield. That is related, so watch tariffs driving up costs. Watch talk about the weakening dollar which imports inflation into this country.

I think the Trump administration, and this is a warning to them. They need to be careful of anything in terms of driving up inflation in the United States borrowing costs at this point, and also how much more money you are going to borrow after we doubled it out during the last administration. Those are very, very big concerns because President Trump love talking about the record breaking run in the stock market. The one thing that will throw cold water on it is much higher borrowing costs. And 2.7, let that be a warning.

BARTIROMO: You are right, and we already saw a come back from South Korea, LG comes out last week and says, oh, guess what we are going to raise prices. So that was as a result of the tariff.

MCDOWELL: I want to say really quickly one thing. These are companies like Samsung that have jobs in the United States. They have a new appliance plant in South Carolina. Part of these tariffs on imported parts above a certain level. If you try to import parts into this country and assemble washing machines and create jobs in the nation, the Republican Governor of South Carolina is very concerned about these tariffs.

BARTIROMO: They have to figure out a way, what's the cost because you can't keep putting a terror retirement crosses the border, because reports are coming from different places. Same issue with autos. Because the parts are coming from different places, so you have got to come up with one tariffs and not have overly done tariffs, if you will.

More to come on that. Coming up terrorism strikes a military school in Afghanistan. We have got that story, the details on the attack that left 11 people dead.

Then the dangerous discovery that is putting our soldiers at risk. A new report shows the fitness devices are exposing sensitive military locations, you've got to hear this. And then Hillary Clinton surprise appearance at the Grammys, the former presidential candidate's latest jab at the commander-in-chief. That is all ahead. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back another deadly attack in Afghanistan to report. Militants reading a military Academy in Kabul. Cheryl Casone with the details in headlines. Cheryl, good morning to you.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN:AM CO-HOST: Good morning. Maria, another attack to talk about there. At least seven soldiers have been killed, 16 others wounded. It was an early morning assault on a military compound in Kabul. The Islamic State group claiming responsibility in this comes only two days after more than 100 people were killed in a suicide attack in the afghan capital. This month alone, more than 200 people have been killed and hundreds wounded in a series of attacks unleashed by the Taliban and their rival, ISIS.

Meanwhile, this is interesting, a popular fitness app is revealing top- secret information about the location of the U.S. military bases. "The Washington Post" reports that the apps draw heatmaps, pinpoint soldier's workouts near previously undisclosed military bases, and some spy outposts. This is part of Strava GPS dealer gathering available on smart phones and yes, the Fitbit. Which a lot of soldiers wear because it's Fitbit.

And there is more fallout today from security flaws that Intel found in its chips. "The Wall Street Journal" reporting that Intel told some Chinese technology companies about the potential problems but not the U.S. government. Security experts say they may have given the Chinese government a heads up about the flaws known as inspector and meltdown. Remember those laws allow hackers to access personal data and researchers say there's no sign the information was ever exploited, shares of Intel Laura new premarket right now more than half a percent.

Apple reportedly cutting its iPhone 10 production in half in the first quarter, this is due to disappointing holiday sales in Europe, the U.S. and China. Japan's Nikkei is reporting that Apple is lowering its production targets to 20 million units. Part of the problem could be Apple's price tag which starts at $1000. Remember, guys, the stock took a hit last week as well. Shares of Apple trading slightly lower in the premarket. Almost half a percent they are reporting by the way later on in the week, guys.

And then finally this, the Grammys. Typically, it is all about music, right. Well, he got really political. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Hip-hop, real talk. That is love, baby. Jay for president.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Tonight, in this room full music dreamers, we remember this country was built by dreamers, for dreamers chasing the American dream, and all I know, it is just like dreams, these kids can't be forgotten. And are worth fighting for.

HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER SECRETARY OF STATE: We have a longtime fear of being poisoned. One reason why he like to eat at McDonald's. Nobody knew he was coming, and the food was tastily made.

(END OF VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: And we should say United States Ambassador to the UN, Nikki Haley, was not happy about this. Here's her tweet, she said I always loved the Grammys, but how artists read the "Fire and Fury" book killed it. Don't ruin great music with trash, some of us love music without the politics thrown in it.

Now back to the music, the big winner of the night was Bruno Mars, he earned the top three awards, he got album of the year for "24k Magic", and he won 6 Grammys told, singer and songwriter Joy Villa, by the way, wore a make America great again dress, remember at the Grammys last year. Well, she's coming up later on the show you new dressed that she wore last night. She is getting a lot of buzz, Maria, about her latest outfit.

BARTIROMO: Yes, her purse said choose life, enter dress was another extension of that. So, she is going to join us and talk more about that. You were the Grammys.

ROSCHELLE: I was.

BARTIROMO: Tell us about it.

ROSCHELLE: It was awesome. Bruno Mars, he was incredible. That was great. But the highlight for me was Elton John, everybody my generation was hanging on for Elton John's performance.

BARTIROMO: And he did a duo with Miley Cyrus. Right before that it's when you saw the "Fire and Fury" book readings, and that's when I turned it off, although my TV was still on and I did see it.

Once I saw the readings on "Fire and Fury", I was like, OK, that's it, I'm done. Did you watch it?

MCDOWELL: I watched some of it. This is what we expect, music is politics. A lot of these musicians there, and for the last 50 years, the music has been filled with political statements, so again that is what you're going to get. Kendrick Lamar, if he hadn't done what he did and that opening number which was incredibly powerful, the people would've been disappointed.

BARTIROMO: You know what though, Bruno Mars did not get political.

MCDOWELL: But his music isn't political. It's when a singer starts making political statements that's out of character. But U2 again, their entire career has been tinged with making political statements.

BARTIROMO: Going into the show, Jay Z it's all about negatives about President Trump. The president actually fought back at them on Twitter.

CARTER: I think it is interesting now that the new elites are in Grammys, are in music or entertainment, in the are completely out of touch with the American public. In it continues.

MCDOWELL: Would they have been able to rally votes, Hillary would have won.

CARTER: That's right.

MCDOWELL: If all the people who listen to their music would have gone out there and voted, she might have won.

BARTIROMO: That's right, they didn't come out. All right, we will take a break, when we come back market momentum rages, the Dow, the Nasdaq, the S&P 500 trading at record highs even we're looking at a fractional pullback this morning. What if anything slows things down for going let take a look at that, the risks. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BENIN VIDEO CLIP)

DAVID BURROUGHS, MECUM AUCTIONS AUTOMOBILE AUTHENTICATION EXPERT: It's about the size of the tip of a ballpoint pen.

JAMIE COLBY, FBN HOST: David Burroughs, Mecum Auctions automobile authentication expert, pinpoints the problem for me.

BURROUGHS: So, if you count in 13 of these ribs would be right about in the center of this little gutter.

COLBY: But it's missing.

BURROUGHS: So restored cars could get all sanded off to make it pretty and shiny, and found that little fingerprint gets obliterated, so that implies that this car has either been restored or at least something is fishy.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: That was a clip from tonight's all new "Strange Inheritance" on Fox Business Network host Jamie Colby set out for Chicago to meet the son of a Vietnam vet was left in mint condition Corvette, in joining us right now, the host of "Strange Inheritance," Jamie Colby. Jamie, what a great story, tell us about this.

COLBY: What a cliffhanger that was.

BARTIROMO: 1967 Corvette Stingray.

COLBY: And they have a little dimple under the hood that was part of the original mold. This car, it was missing. With the son of this Vietnam veteran who sent his combat pay home to give him an incentive to come out alive and make it back, he treated this as well as his five children. In the son inherited it and realized he could not divided into three, for his kids when he passed, so he finally decides to sell it. But he only wanted to go to a family that will appreciate story behind it about his father.

And Mecum Auctions actually did propose that this car was special, not only it sold $675,000 but it had incredible military story behind it, and what an honor for me to pay tribute to our troops by telling the story of this Vietnam veteran tonight. But that little divot missing. It is an authentication issue.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

COLBY: You have to watch to find out.

BARTIROMO: We will. It's a great story. All of these stories are so fascinating, I want to take a clip of the second episode airing at 9:30 eastern tonight. What's this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHARLOTTE SMITH, COLLECTOR OF CLOTHES: I just lost my job. And I thought I am actually a two homeowner because my collection actually cost me more than maintaining my house.

COLBY: Charlotte can only afford to keep one.

SMITH: It was awful, but you know what I just thought there is no way I would inherit a collection like this for no reason. I made the decision I'd rather sell my house than my collection.

COLBY: Now, think about that. First addresses cost her, her shop, next the cost her, her husband, now for cost her, her house.

(END OF VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: She's giving everything up except the clothes.

COLBY: Here's the amazing thing and we are learning a lot from viewers writing us, her godmother was a Quaker. The last fashionista that you would imagine. She got $25 from her parents and bought her first dress, in turn it was out of control.

3000 dresses that were left to Charlotte Smith who was an antique shop owner in Australia, and she has one of the most significant and historic fashion collections. Her husband said, it's me or the clothes, babe. And she said. Bye bye.

And she has made a career, she said this is not just a collection, it is a calling. She has written a book on Dior, she has written a book on Chanel, the collection is priceless we saw it here in New York at Parsons. And wait until you see what she's done with it, but a Quaker very unlikely, but a great story of her and Matt, also the first gentleman who inherited the Corvette wanted to do the right thing. Twists and turns tonight, Maria. If you watch one night of "Strange Inheritance" this season, this is it.

BARTIROMO: I'll be watching. Jamie, great show. Congrats.

COLBY: Thank you, Maria, great to see you, don't forget that money collection you have, the coins and the dollars. I'm waiting.

BARTIROMO: I collect currency. One of these days I'm going to bring it in and show everybody. Thank you so much, Jamie Colby there. Check out "Strange Inheritance" tonight.

BARTIROMO: Two iPads.

FARMESCHI: Yes, yes, yes. Two iPads, all both touchscreen so you can go and surf here in the navi system into the infotainment system, and you can also with the sensor levers select the driving modes; you can drive in a comfortable way, you can have a sporty way, race way, but also this is the new speaker.

BARTIROMO: So, it's almost like autonomous?

FARMESCHI: It's not exactly autonomous.

BARTIROMO: It's not exactly autonomous because you can't stop and not -- you can't control.

FARMESCHI: (INAUDIBLE) the driver is always at the center, because we speak about emotions, and for us, driving the Lamborghini is key, all of our clients want to drive their Lamborghini.

BARTIROMO: It's fantastic.

FARMESCHI: And in terms of support, the driver, we also provide the technology to help the driver, so recently in this car, we have a full advance driver assistance system that helps the driver in case of a imminent crash to break the car and talk to support in case (INAUDIBLE) situation the driver.

BARTIROMO: Yes, which is why we talked all about autos at the CES Show, the technology show, because technology is in all of the cars. Alessandro, this is beautiful, the moment I stepped in the car, I could tell you I'm in a Lamborghini. It's absolutely gorgeous, it's the Urus, and Alessandro Farmeschi, it is good to see you. Thank you so much for joining us.

FARMESCHI: My pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Stay with us. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Once again, our thanks to Lamborghini and Alessandro Farmeschi, thanks for showing me around this high-tech car. Thank you, Dagen McDowell, Mitch Roschelle, and Lee Carter. We'll see you again tomorrow, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins right now. Stuart, over to you.

VARNEY: Maria, thank you very much indeed. Now, this is not the way we usually open the show. It's

END
