urn:contentItem:5KKJ-P7P1-DXH2-61VM-00000-00Clinton Team Getting Personality Profile on Trump; Rush Limbaugh on 49ers QB; FBI Discusses Russian Hacking; FBI Will Release Hillary Clinton Interview Notes To The Public; Ten Thousand Syrian Refugees Have Entered the U.S.2016-08-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:52ZLexisNexisRISK & REWARD5:00 PM ESTArt Laffer, Christopher Bedford, Richard Goodstein, Fred Barnes, James Scott, Ed Rollins, Tom FittonNEWSDomestic083001cb.233Clinton Team Getting Personality Profile on Trump; Rush Limbaugh on 49ers QB; FBI Discusses Russian Hacking; FBI Will Release Hillary Clinton Interview Notes To The Public; Ten Thousand Syrian Refugees Have Entered the U.S.Deirdre Bolton, Keith Ablow, David Webb

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: It's a crooked system, it's a system that's rigged. It's a rigged, crooked system. First of all it's rigged. I'm afraid the election will be rigged.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FBN HOST: The FBI is state officials about the possibility of hackers breaking into computer network.

This is Risk & Reward. I'm Deirdre Bolton.

A Russian hackers gained access to log in credential used by Arizona state election officials. The system of Illinois was also breached.

So, it's worth noting that today in Arizona there is a primary with House and Senate candidates competing.

With me now, my colleague, Blake Burman. So, Blake, what is the latest?

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hi there, Deirdre. Two well-known senators on the ballot tonight. You mentioned Arizona, Florida as well. But both are expected to defeat their primary challengers. We'll begin with John McCain, he is seeking the term in Arizona. He is being pushed especially hard on immigration by the state Senator Dr. Kelly Ward.

Also tonight, after repeatedly promising to not run for his Senate seat. Marco Rubio on the ballot, again in Florida. He is expected to breeze through despite $8 million worth of spending from business Carlos Beruff.

The race in Florida, though that is really gathering the national attention is the congressional fight in the Miami area, the ousted DNC chair Debbie Wasserman Shultz is now trying to fight off Tim Canova who was backed by Bernie Sanders.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM CANOVA, FORMER CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE: Our campaigns are different. We don't take any money from any corporate interests. None of their PACS or super PACS, and it leaves us free to represent the people. I like to send bought and paid for by the people.

DEBBIE WASSERMAN SCHULTZ, FORMER DEMOCRATIC NATIONAL COMMITTEE CHAIRWOMAN: They want to know they have a fighter, and they want to know that if someone who knows their way of life that has been in the community like I have for 30 years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: And, Deirdre, as you mentioned there are fresh concerns about the safety of our elections. Just this day the outgoing Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid has sent a letter to the head of the FBI James Comey asking him to investigated if Russia is trying to temper with our elections. Deirdre?

BOLTON: Yes. He sent that in a very strangely worded letter. We're going to talk more about that. Blake Burman, thank you very much. I know coming back to you in a little bit for an update on Hillary Clinton's e-mail.

But in the meantime, election say just two months away, So, November 8 on most voters' calendars, and before that, millions of voters can vote early in some states as early as September. No matter how and when you vote. There is a new report that shows that rigging the presidential elect would be easy.

Here is part of that report. "The United States e-voting system is so vulnerable that a small group of one of a few dedicated individual could linchpin district of a swing state and sway the entire presidential election."

The co-author of that report is here now. He is a cyber-expert, James Scott. James, welcome to Risk & Reward. So, with all due respect, are you exaggerating this claim? I mean, is it really that easy, and I'm taking the language from your report to rig an election?

JAMES SCOTT, CYBER SECURITY EXPERT: Yes. In the beginning we thought it would be more complicated. Hewlett-Packard security gave us this project and said to find if it is truly as this vulnerable as people are saying.

When we got into the cyber physical and technical aspects we found the entire system is rigged with vulnerabilities from the regional level to the state. So, yes, you know it is unfortunately.

BOLTON: So, James, let's just say for a hacker, one being the easiest, 10 being the hardest. I'm leaving all the amateurs out, what is the exact level of difficulty; just give us a sense of range.

SCOTT: Sure. A hacker can use to go in the deep web and go on the marketplace download a variant of malware that self-deletes. Take it, put it on an USB drive with acetone then take acetone a bump key and a razor blade, go into a church basement or a school boiler room where these voting machines are warehoused. Seamlessly get through the certified audit tag.

BOLTON: So, James, would you say more than half of the cyber expert out there could do this?

SCOTT: I think this is so easy a script kitty could do it.

BOLTON: OK. That's pretty frightening but I'm glad to have your perspective on that.

SCOTT: Yes. From a state perspective if you are looking larger, instead of going in and taking advantage of a local election, you could go in at the state level with more equipped malware and basic spear phishing attack with a product update for some type of technology. It could be Adobe even and that could deliver malicious payload there with the key logger that could record key strokes. Trojan which would create a back door. A remote access Trojan...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: And we've heard of all of these through businesses. And of course, part of the weakest link is that in a lot of these campaigns, especially at the local level, some are volunteer employees, they may innocently click on a link is filled with malware as you rightly point out.

James, come back.

SCOTT: Yes.

BOLTON: Chances are we're going to be talking about this again. We thank you in the meantime. Thanks for the report.

SCOTT: Thank you very much.

BOLTON: James Scott, cyber expert.

Hacks have many on edge. Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid writing a letter to the FBI director James Comey calling on investigators to make any information that they find public. So here is one part of the letter. This is what Blake Burman, my colleague was just talking about.

"The evidence of a direct connection between the Russian government and Donald Trump's presidential campaign continues to mount and has led Michael Morrell, former acting CIA director to call Trump an unwitting agent of Russia and the Kremlin."

Co-chairman of Trump's Great America PAC, Ed Rollins is with me now. Ed, wonderful to see you.

ED ROLLINS, TRUMP'S GREAT AMERICA PAC CO-CHAIR: Thank you. Nice to be with you.

BOLTON: So, Harry Reid is alleging that Russians essentially are attempting to help Donald Trump win the presidential election. And this is a theory that some other democrats have put forward. But I want to be clear, the White House has not touched this, neither has the FBI, neither has the CIA. How far-fetched is this?

ROLLINS: Harry Reid over time has said some pretty far-fetched concept. And I think this is more political than it is anything with any real facts. Who knows who Putin wants? Would he want four more years of an Obama-type administration that's not been very powerful and certainly not done have much.

Or that he want Trump kind of an unknown. So, Trump says he's never met Putin, I take him at his word. So, I don't think they're playing in our politics although the story you just head-on to me as someone who has been in the game for 50 years, it's kind of frightening to think that you can go and alter a few states. I know in very close election it just...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: Well, I don't mean to be dismissive.

ROLLINS: No, no.

BOLTON: For example, call him, you know, something like Oliver Stone which is why I wanted to ask.

ROLLINS: As I was watching it, and I have a tendency to always kind of dismiss theories of election fraud although I've been certainly around enough to know that there are some of it. But when you'd know all of the things that have happened with computers and what have you, I just hope that you really do have the resources to go guard against this.

Because again, you're talking not about 50 state campaigns, you're talking about seven or eight states that will make the difference in this electoral and that probably comes down to 20 or 30 counties in those states that can make a difference. So, I hope there is due diligence and I'm sure there will be.

BOLTON: And I'm sure for people who remember the Cold War, the idea of Russia trying to influence what we're doing here is very real in a way that it may not be to millennials.

ROLLINS: Well, I think -- I think the reality is that the computer hacking has become such a part of our life and unfortunate part of life that we've just never thought about it coming in and trying to transform election job is very critical, very important.

BOLTON: Ed, let me ask you about something going on the other side of the aisle.

ROLLINS: Sure.

BOLTON: The New York Times editorial board have published key web states that "Hillary Clinton must cut ties to the Clinton Foundation." Now the Trump campaign did make a statement. I'm going to read part of it. He says, the campaign says, "The fact that even the liberal New York Times thinks the Clinton Foundation presents an unacceptable conflict of interest is a devastating rebuke of Hillary Clinton's poor judgment and broken ethical compass. At a minimum, Hillary Clinton should help the growing calls for her corrupt foundation to seize accepting foreign and corporate contributions immediately. With each donation she becomes more and more compromised."

So, it does seem as if Hillary Clinton should at the very least step away from this.

ROLLINS: Far away I never, could never understand why she joined the foundation after she was Secretary of State. She obviously could make a lot of money going out and doing speeches.

But I think to a certain extent she didn't think politically unless she was using that as a resource to basically build a political campaign to take care of friends and allies. She now has a liability that she shouldn't have.

And I think just a mere fact that if I become president I'm not going to take any funds there or have any funds. She promised that when she became Secretary of State and obviously violated it and it's a big, big issue to a lot of people out there.

BOLTON: Ed, let me ask you from the liberal side of the bench, the idea is that, oh, this foundation does such good work. That if she steps out, it loses its name work and it loses its founder. And I've heard people say, listen, look at Bill Gates. There are many people who run very successful foundations where she could give the money.

ROLLINS: There are billions and billions of dollars that are raised to do wonderful things around the world and the Clinton Foundation in some cases have. Its unfortunate it has tainted by foreign people who have come in and made enormous sums of money had gotten access to certain things, nuclear access, nuclear resources and what have you.

Certain people had a vested interest in becoming part of that. And I think that it's getting more and more exposed, and I think to a certain extent it's one of the liabilities that she has.

BOLTON: Yes. And I mean, if I were working on her campaign as a strategist, let's say you already have the e-mail...

(CROSSTALK)

ROLLINS: Absolutely, you don't need this.

BOLTON: ... you don't need a second shadow over your shoulder.

ROLLINS: And particularly with this, there has always been a question of her integrity. The Clintons have always basically had everything up for pay.

BOLTON: You go back to the Lincoln bedrooms.

ROLLINS: Bedrooms and the rides on Air Force One and what have you. So, my sense it was foolish of her to get back into it. At this point in time she ought to clean it up and turn it over to one of these foundations to run and let the good stuff work its way out.

BOLTON: Speaking of turning over a new leaf, tomorrow in ArizonaDonald Trump is making a key speech on immigration. Former Mayor of New York City, Rudy Giuliani made this comment about Trump's stance. Here is the former mayor.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP).

RUDY GIULIANI, FORMER NEW YORK CITY MAYOR: He is going to go after the most dangerous first, then the less dangerous criminals second. And by the time we get there then we'll see what our population is of non-criminal illegal immigrants.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: So, Ed, speaking of strategies some have criticized Donald Trump in the past 10 days saying he's waffling a bit on his stance on immigration. So, tomorrow the speech comes. What does he need to say?

ROLLINS: He needs to be very clear in what he stets. I mean, he started off being the most anti-immigrant and obviously made distance between some of his other opponents in the primary. I would say he has waffled a little bit. I think it's a complex issue and I think he's finding out more and more about that and the difficulty of the task. But at the same time, as he goes in two months to go or 70 days to go. He has to be very clear what his positions are.

BOLTON: Because President Bush Sr. said read my lips, no new tax, it generate taxes and it really hurt him. So, it feels like this could be a comparable issue for Donald Trump.

ROLLINS: He can say it's complicated. I'm going to to the Congress to ask for certain things, but at the end of the day, here are the things I believe I'm going to do.

BOLTON: All right. Ed Rollins, clarity, we love it. Thank you.

ROLLINS: All right. My pleasure. Thank you.

BOLTON: Ed Rollins. Be sure to catch Fox Business Network's special coverage of Donald Trump's immigration speech. That starts tomorrow night at 7 p.m. Eastern Time.

Fox has confirmed the FBI will release Hillary Clinton interview notes to the public. We're going to bring you all the details. And on a related note, the State Department says 30 Benghazi-related e-mails were in the batch of 15,000 that the FBI said Hillary Clinton didn't turn over.

Judicial Watch president Tom Fitton sued the government under the Freedom of Information Act to get this data. He's with me next.

BOLTON: There are two new developments concerning Hillary Clinton's e- mails. So, one, the FBI is planning to release the notes from its closed door interview with Hillary Clinton. Second development, the State Department says about 30 e-mails were recovered, ones that involve references to the 2012 Benghazi attack.

Blake Burman back with me now with more. So, Blake, how are these two moving parts fitting together?

BURMAN: You're right, Deirdre, there are two different stories here. Let's start with the first. Where sources tell Fox that the FBI is repairing a release of some materials contained in the bureau's report of the Hillary Clinton e-mail investigation.

You'll remember that this is a part of three and a half hour interview of the former Secretary of State that took place a couple of months ago over the 4th of July weekend. Now I could tell you there is no exact time frame for the release. But it is expected soon.

Earlier today, the White House Secretary Josh Earnest tried to distance the White House from the process. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOSH EARNEST, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: I can tell you that the White House did not consult with the FBI about that decision or any of the other decisions that they've made in terms of handling some of the investigative material.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Topic number two, this comes as at least 30 previously deleted e- mails from Clinton's State Department tenure relating to Benghazi will soon be released. Donald Trump's campaign reacting today with the statement that says in part, quote, "If Clinton did not consider e-mails about something as important as Benghazi to be work-related, one has to wonder what is contained in the other e-mails she attempted to wipe from her server."

That's the statement today from the Trump campaign. Deirdre?

BOLTON: Blake, thank you as always. Blake Burman on both of those developing stories.

Well, when questioned as to why she didn't turn over these e-mails, here's what Hillary Clinton said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HILLARY CLINTON, (D) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I chose not to keep my private personal e-mails. E-mails about planning Chelsea's wedding or my mother's funeral arrangements, condolence notes to friends as well as yoga routines, family vacations.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: The State Department as we just talked about with Blake, confirming that 30 Benghazi-related e-mails have been found, have been recovered, it's the better way to put it.

Judicial Watch president, author of "Clean House" Tom Fitton is with me now. Tom, welcome and congratulations because you had to sue the government under the Freedom of Information Act to even get access to this data and provide essentially a service to the American public. So, do you feel you can do a victory lap or it is still too early?

TOM FITTON, JUDICIAL WATCH PRESIDENT: Well, it's kind of outrageous. They told us they found some Benghazi materials last week, and they said they give them to us in the beginning the end of September. We said how many e- mails are we talking about? They didn't want to tell us.

So, we had a court hearing to get that one piece of information. Thirty e- mails they wanted to the end of September within one e-mail a day to review and release them. And I'm not even sure all of them are necessarily responsive per se or it can be released.

It's just absurd and the court pressured the administration, given the national interests of this material to move more quickly and demanded a report, a status report on September 6 next week and denied the State Department's request for more time.

BOLTON: So, Tom, let me ask you to put on a different hat if you don't mind. Why do you think this drip, drip, drip approach somehow serves the other side? I don't even understand that.

FITTON: Well, by delaying, there is an effort to delay. I mean, this is in July they received these e-mails, these are the emails the FBI recovered that Mrs. Clinton tried to delete. Now it turns out they are not yoga e- mails in there, there may be, but now there is Benghazi e-mails in there and they've been sitting on those for a month, and they didn't want to tell us they had 30 e-mails. They want to take as long as two extra months to turn them over.

So, it's obviously a political delay. Mrs. Clinton never wanted anyone to see these e-mails because they were deleted. And that she deleted them. And the ones she did turn over and she never turned over voluntarily to begin with.

This is just a further an indication, and further indication that the Clinton-Obama crowd are allied and withholding and delaying the release of information about Mrs. Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State to the American people.

BOLTON: Tom, that is the e-mail, the Benghazi-related e-mails that were recovered separately as Blake Burman was just telling us. The FBI Is going to release the notes, most people were under the impression those notes. Previously most people already know the impression wouldn't be released. But from the private closed door interview that it had with Hillary Clinton. What do you think we are going to learn?

FITTON: We are going to learn what Mrs. Clinton told the FBI and how half- baked the FBI investigation was, given that the outcome. We've been asking for these notes as well and we were going to sue if we don't get them. And we may still sue because there were other interviews that took place that may not be released.

So, we'll see what's released in the end and what's withheld. On top of that we just submitted questions to Mrs. Clinton today, we sent it over to her lawyer that she's going to have to respond to under oath. So, you know, trust Judicial Watch to get some answers under oath from Mrs. Clinton presumably that the FBI was unable to get.

You know, she up ended the Freedom of Information Act in a way that we are still dealing with today. We had three government lawyers in federal court trying to tell the American people why they need to wait as long as two months for 30 or at least one month for 30 e-mails to be released. And thank you, Mrs. Clinton for setting that up.

BOLTON: All right. Tom Fitton, thank you so much for the time and for your work as it highlighted many people...

FITTON: Thank you. You're welcome, Deirdre.

BOLTON: ... point out you are doing a service to the U.S. that no one else is.

The E.U. is trying to get Apple to pay more than $14 billion in back taxes. This is the biggest demand ever. My next guest says Apple and other American companies are keeping their money overseas because of a broken U.S. corporate tax policy.

Former Reagan economic adviser Art Laffer is with me.

BOLTON: The E.U. is charging Apple to pay more than $14 billion in back taxes. So, this is the biggest tax ruling ever for a single company. The charge? Apple artificially lowered its tax bill for more than 20 years with Ireland's permission.

So, both Apple and the Irish government say they will fight the ruling. U.S. Treasury Department also suggesting there would be consequences for the E.U. commission if the matter could not be resolved with all parties sitting around the same table.

Some say the issue looming in the background is a broken U.S. corporate tax policy. American corporate tax rates are near 40 percent compared to Irelands which total around 14 percent. Some democrats in the U.S. want corporate rates to go even higher.

Former economic adviser to President Reagan, Art Laffer is with me now. So, Art, are we forcing companies such as Apple, and Apple is not alone, there is also Amazon, there is also McDonald's, essentially are we forcing them to search for their own tax solutions?

ART LAFFER, FORMER REAGAN ECONOMIC ADVISER: Well, of course, I mean, that's what we're doing. I mean, we have the highest single tax rate on corporations in the OECD and obviously these companies want after-tax returns so they choose to move to different locations.

Now Ireland is the best in the world. I mean, very close to it. It's a 12.5 percent federal tax in Ireland, so it's very easy to speak English. They are wonderful people, some of us are even descended from them. So, it's just great!

And it's a terrific thing, and Ireland has made one huge mistake, and that's not leaving the E.U. It should leave the E.U. and join the U.K., they should be next in Brexit, and they could be the center focal point, the Interpol of the English speaking world. And, Deirdre, I think that would be just great.

BOLTON: Well, with a first name like Deirdre, I have to say I have in Dublin a few times and when you go into that before you come from...

(CROSSTALK)

LAFFER: Dublin (Ph) is wonderful.

BOLTON: Yes. And when you go into the airport, I mean, you see all these big tech companies and Ireland has made it their business to attract those companies but the E.U. is now mad. I'm glad you brought up Brexit.

LAFFER yes.

BOLTON: Many people say, you know what? Ireland pulls the trick...

(CROSSTALK)

LAFFER: Ireland should get out of there.

BOLTON: .. that the E.U. just didn't think of first and that group is seeking revenge.

LAFFER: yes, that's true. In fact I've got an old joke that I should you, do you know why everyone is investing in Ireland?

BOLTON: no.

LAFFER: Because the capital is always Dublin!

BOLTON: Yes. I love it, Art. I love it.

(CROSSTALK)

LAFFER: Dublin never mind, Deirdre.

BOLTON: Jokes and economic sense all wrapped up in one brain. But let me ask you this.

LAFFER: Sure.

BOLTON: I mean, in order to prevent corporate inversions, that is to say U.S. companies from buying companies overseas just to move their headquarters benefit from lower tax rates, both candidates have very different plans.

Trump wants to offer a kind of amnesty, let companies bring money back, pay a onetime 10 percent fee and move on. Hillary Clinton is more punitive.

LAFFER: Yes, Hillary Clinton wants to punish them for being there. I mean, you know, you can't tax an economy into prosperity and that is Hillary's model. Now Donald Trump wants to bring them back, but he has a very high tax and it should be much lower than 10 percent.

Ten percent in many cases would be the whole tax savings the companies have gotten garnered over there. So, it should be lower than 10 percent, but his point is correct. Bring them back, let them provide jobs, help with employment in America, why not?

BOLTON: Why not, indeed? Do you think Hillary Clinton is being pushed to the left, obviously Senator Sanders no longer in the race, but I never heard her say anything like that before Sanders.

LAFFER: Well, she hasn't that I don't know of before. But, you know, it makes no sense whatsoever. You can't be pushed left if you don't believe left. I mean, you know, they can't push to you do something, Deirdre, that you don't believe in. And they can't push to you say a lie, can they?

I mean, no one can. And if she is repeating this type of stuff, she obviously has some portion in her down deep that sort of agrees with it and makes no sense to me. Let me just explain, if you have two locations a and b, Deirdre, and if you raise taxes in b and you lower in a, producers and manufacturers and people are going to move from, b to a.

It's not rocket surgery as Larry Gatlin says every now and then. It's just common sense! People go to where they have the best situation. And that's Ireland and the countries and that's in Tennessee in the states.

BOLTON: Art, let me shift gears if you don't mind.

LAFFER: Sure.

BOLTON: Ten thousand Syrian refugees have entered the U.S., so that reaches the Obama administration's goal. Donald Trump and other republicans are calling for an end to the program. Hillary Clinton calling for a 550 percent expansion based on figures that could mean a population of more than 600,000, so nearly the population of Detroit.

And in February, oddly enough, President Bill Clinton suggested that Syrian refugees move to Detroit and help revive the city, which many people don't understand the connection, but do you see it?

LAFFER: I don't see the connection at all. I mean, this Syrian refugee thing is way outside of my candor, Deirdre, and I didn't really know how to handle it.

Now, on illegal aliens down the southern border of the United States in Mexico and the U.S., these people are wonderful people who are here to work, to produce, they are high-quality labor at low cost and they really provide a lot of benefits to the U.S.

But that's people who come to the U.S. for economic reasons, and when you're talking about Syria and the Middle East and all these turmoil driven by war and driven by attacks and deaths and all, that it's a very different motive set and it's not one that I can talk to very easily, I really can't, Deirdre.

But the southern migration is all economic, all out of Nicaragua and Costa Rica and Mexico, and South America, these people are coming to the U.S. because we have jobs, high-paying jobs, they're needed here badly and they have high-quality skills.

BOLTON: All right. Art Laffer, we thank you as always. Glad to have you.

LAFFER: Thank you very much, Deirdre.

BOLTON: A new report shows the Obama administration is taking billion dollar big bank settlement and funneling that money to favorite liberal political groups.

The Daily Caller's Christopher Bedford has the evidence. He's with me next.

BOLTON: A new report shows the Obama administration is funneling millions of dollars in banks settlement cash to approved liberal groups. So, big banks paid billions of dollars in settlements after the financial crisis. That combined amount close to $11 billion is apparently being funneled into liberal political groups such as La Raza, the National Urban League, and the National Community Reinvestment Coalition.

My next guest says this is an old trick, editor-in-chief of the Daily Caller news foundation, Christopher Bedford with me now. Chris, welcome back. So, where did we said, coming from the big banks, we showed people where it's going but how is it happening?

CHRISTOPHER BEDFORD, THE DAILY CALLER ASSOCIATE EDITOR: So, consumers and taxpayers may expect that when these millions of dollars or billions of dollars are taken from this bank because of promise -- problems with their business dealings, so that's going to go back to refunding the taxpayer or to giving them some kind of relief.

But it turns out no. There is actually a system that's really well put in place. To get this money to go to community outreach groups, places like they got council of La Raza, places like Catholic charities which is not a leftist group, that's an exception and the urban League.

And this is an old system. You have to remember that the president got his start before the Senate as a community organizer. And there's a lot of people, activists outside government and inside government that they funnel this money in, they find the banks, the money goes back to the left-wing groups, the left-wing group sue again and this is repudiate system where the banks lose but they don't want to fight back.

BOLTON: So, Chris, you mentioned this is an old trick. Where have you seen this before?

BEDFORD: The EPA is one place you should look for it all the time. Environmental groups which are largely the groups that they are alumni's, staffed the EPA. They sue the government over different regulations, things that they want.

The government responds by finding different groups, finding energy companies and then they send that money right back to the EPA or to the environmental activists groups to start it all over again. It's very common, especially in environmentalism.

BOLTON: And as you say, the visual of a cycle is apt. President Obama meeting with Health and Human Services today this scrambling huge put forth a 300-page fix to ObamaCare. There's a new report out that says nearly a third of U.S. counties will be left with only one insurance option on the ObamaCare exchanges next year.

So, that seems like dire news for anybody who needs to buy health insurance?

BEDFORD: It is absolutely dire news and it's going to affect more than 20 million people. There is even one county in the United States, it's not right now currently doesn't have any insurer that want to do this, and a large part is because ObamaCare hasn't hit its projections.

They're expecting over 20 million people to be signed up for ObamaCare, we're less than half of that. And as a consequence, the number of insurance companies are losing money and are pulling out of markets and it's going to leave people in a bind. Because when there's no competition in the marketplace, their premiums are going to go up, up, up.

BOLTON: So, Chris, one of the flaws that experts have talked to us about is that the Obama administration expected just as many young, healthy people to sign up, that's the mandates, as poorer, more sick people who needed more service to sign up and that didn't happen?

BEDFORD: That didn't happen; they haven't made a number of their projections. That's one example. Also they expected that businesses would push their employees off and push them into the marketplace, and that hasn't happened.

And then you're seeing right now that the White House is trying to spin this, like, oh, well, none of this happened so everything is failing. But it's a good thing that people haven't been pushed into the marketplace.

And you're seeing government economics at their most hysterical, when everyone's premiums are rising and rising and the government says, don't worry we'll just pay more for it, never actually realize that the reason why everything is becoming more expensive is because they've gotten involved in the first place.

BOLTON: Christopher Bedford, we thank you as always.

BEDFORD: Thank you.

BOLTON: Glad to have your insight.

A new report shows Hillary Clinton's team is getting advice from psychology experts to create a personality profile of Donald Trump.

My next guest says the only person who needs a psychological profile is Hillary Clinton. Dr. Keith Ablow is with me next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DAVID PLOUFFE, FORMER OBAMA CAMPAIGN MANAGER: I think the assessment was that Donald Trump would try and do some things to appeal to the middle of the electorate, to appeal to suburban college educated women, He's not. I mean, basically you have a psychopath running for president. I mean, he meets the clinical definition, OK?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: A new report shows that Hillary Clinton's campaign is getting advice from psychology experts to create a personality profile of Donald Trump. So, the Clinton campaign is supposedly looking for trigger points and compiling a strategy when Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton are one on one on a debate stage.

My next guest says Hillary Clinton is the one in need of psychological profile. Fox News contributor, psychiatrist and author Dr. Keith Ablow is with me now. Dr. Ablow, welcome back.

KEITH ABLOW, FOX NEWS MEDICAL A-TEAM: Thanks for having me.

BOLTON: How would you evaluate Hillary Clinton?

ABLOW: Well, listen, first of all, as to the psychological profile of Donald Trump, I can save them time, 30 seconds. The guy's addicted to the truth. He blurts it out. He's inelegant at times but that's because he really wants to address things in unadulterated, straightforward way and it does get him in trouble sometimes.

He says more in a dramatic way than his heart really means, right? He's a good and decent guy who goes overboard and says extreme things. OK, his psychological profile is over.

Now for hers, we have somebody who can be understood as wanting one thing and only one thing, power. She was willing to have a sham marriage to her husband which was riddled with his affections for other women throughout the marriage, and she was willing to demonize those women, why? And to stay with her husband, why? Power.

That's the only reason, that's all you need to understand for Hillary Clinton is for some reason I leave this to her psychologist, God willing she gets one and her.

For some reason she feels disempowered to such an extent in her soul that she must get power in any possible way. Hence, when she's Secretary of State and people say, man, your performance led to the death of American servicemen, she says what difference does that make? But she's telling you the truth because the question is did it diminish my power in the world? No.

BOLTON: Such a different perspective.

(CROSSTALK)

ABLOW: And that's all that matters.

BOLTON: So, let me ask you this, speaking of power and speaking of political couples that are in the spotlight. A top Clinton aide Huma Abedin announcing she's leaving her husband Anthony Weiner, it is following his third sexting scandal.

Donald Trump connected it to Hillary, actually put out a statement and it said, "Hillary Clinton was careless and negligent in allowing Weiner to have close proximity to highly classified information. Who knows what he learned and who he told?"

So, obviously the implication is that Huma Abedin may have left a phone, a Blackberry or files around that her spouse may have had access to. Do you think this shows bad judgment on a leader's part?

ABLOW: Well, it does because who knows what this lunatic was told, in other words. You know, this is a woman's husband, presumably, it's not something that you know you live with a wall inside your home, such that there's no communication, so we have someone who is very vulnerable who at any time can feel that his political or journalistic or business future is on the line, and that somebody holds the keys to it.

We know that people can be hacked. So, here's a very vulnerable person who is getting information or has access to information that may be classified or that may be misused and lead to Americans being in harm's way. Of course that's crazy carelessness.

But again, Hillary Clinton, the question isn't whether it's careless, it isn't whether we might suffer. The question is, is it going to lead to less power for me, Hillary Clinton in the answer is no. I seem to be doing OK in the polls, I could get the corner office. I've been willing to swallow this horrible relationship with my husband, I've been willing to tolerate the deaths of American servicemen.

This is nothing, a separate server? I think I can get the corner office and be more powerful despite all of these negative detracting things for the American people. We're going to pay the price if she's elected for her having felt tremendously disempowered at some point in her life, probably very early in her life.

BOLTON: Well, she's even spoken about that. Dr. Keith Ablow, thank you very much for a different perspective. We're glad to have you.

ABLOW: All right. Well, thank you so much.

BOLTON: Conservative radio host, Rush Limbaugh calling out national anthem protesting 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick. More after this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RUSH LIMBAUGH, CONSERVATIVE RADIO HOST: It's ironic that we have now a quarterback who was adopted and raised by a white family, who was scouted and signed by white scouts, was employed by white owners, the National Football League, decides now to steal the stage of the National Football League to make personal statements during the week he is about to be cut.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Conservative talk show host Rush Limbaugh on 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick, the QB wanted to make a statement about police treatment of minorities by refusing to stand for the national anthem.

My all-star panel is here, democratic strategist Richard Goodstein, the Weekly Standard's Fred Barnes; and radio host David Webb. Welcome to you all. So, Richard, do you agree with Rush Limbaugh? Or is this unfair?

RICHARD GOODSTEIN, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: I don't agree with Rush Limbaugh on much of anything. Here's what I agree with. There's a time and a place for everything, OK? When Colin Kaepernick signed with the team, there were certain rules and presumably either he took his paycheck and went by them or he didn't.

Where I disagree and you didn't show this, was Donald Trump's reaction which is always looking through trying to pit blacks against whites and trying to kind of see through things to a kind of crass racial prism, which resulted in his tweet after Dwayne Wade's cousin and after the Orlando shooter.

It would never, ever dawn on Donald Trump to actually address maybe whatever it is that Colin Kaepernick is protesting, which is why the Weekly Standard talked about his outreach to the black community as being cartoonish. So, yes, I kind of understand Rush's point.

BOLTON: So, Richard, hold the thought. Because we do have Donald Trump's reaction, here's his comment.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I think it's a terrible thing, and, you know, maybe you should find a country that works better for him. Let him try. It won't happen.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: So, Fred, by Donald Trump's standards, that was a very muted thoughtful response, many people say, even his critics said, you know what? That's pretty OK. If he wants to find a better country, let him go. What do you think?

FRED BARNES, WEEKLY STANDARD EXECUTIVE EDITOR: I don't think -- I don't think Donald Trump is the issue here at all. Kaepernick is, and I think you have to put -- I'm not that -- I'm not that upset about Kaepernick because you have to put it in perspective.

Go back to the Olympics. Remember the 12 basketball players standing while The Star-Spangled Banner was played because they've won the gold. Eleven African-Americans and the 12th was biracial all with hands over their hearts.

Remember the gymnast Gabby Douglas who got so criticized because she, when was standing there with some other gymnast for a gold medal gymnasts didn't have her hand over her heart. She said later she wasn't protesting. She was proud to be there to win the gold for herself and for her country, so.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: Yes. She said she was standing up straight, she has family members and service and she clarified the comments.

BARNES: Look, when you see those things, the basketball players and Gabby Douglas, I think this Kaepernick thing looms pretty small.

BOLTON: OK, looms pretty small. David, what is your take? I mean, he seems to be a bit younger and greener in many ways in the kindest of terms. I mean, there was a scuffle that he had last year with his teammates. There's a long list of...

(CROSSTALK)

DAVID WEBB, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Yes, where he called his teammate the "n" word.

BOLTON: Yes, and apparently was screaming. I mean, it seems like he's just looking for trouble?

WEBB: Well, I don't know what he's looking for but at some point you're a grown man. I agree by the way, he has a right to do it, those that have raised their right hand they did defend anyone's right to do this. That's not the issue neither is Trump the issue.

The issue is the false narrative here. Kaepernick sits, he doesn't stand. Dwayne Wade's cousin, Nykea Aldridge is killed in Chicago by two black criminals, the Sorrels brothers, 22 and 26, Beyonc‚ Black Lives Matters on stage, but are Beyonc‚ calling Kaepernick and those mothers going to go to the funeral of Nykea Aldridge. There's the fair question. What's the action that follows?

BOLTON: How invested are you?

WEBB: How invested are you in the truth and the reality of dealing with this? So, Richard can try to make it about Trump. Frankly, let's make it about the issue and really talk about the issue of what's going on in black and frankly, economically disparate communities.

BOLTON: So, Richard, David just brought in Beyonc‚, the fact that she stole a bit of a production line from the DNC. She invited the moms of fallen citizens, those who sometimes, well, let's just say, had scuffles with police, ended up dead, some cases were dismissed. Some cases took...

(CROSSTALK)

WEBB: Two were outright criminals.

LEMON: Two were outright criminals. What is your sense on why this is such a big part of the conversation?

GOODSTEIN: Well, I don't think it is a big part of the conversation. Look, I think - I think Donald Trump is actually trying to put the focus on the question of whose better for black community, democrats or republicans, and the fact of the matter is we've had a test case here.

Under the Bill Clinton administration, we actually had the biggest increase in wealth for the black community ever. Under the Bush administration, the biggest collapse, under Obama, 77 straight months of private sector growth. I would welcome that to be.

(CROSSTALK)

WEBB: So, I think revisionist history, Richard. I love revisionist history. Who was in charge of Congress under the Clinton administration?

GOODSTEIN: Good. I'm giving -- I'm tipping my...

WEBB: So, what was that guy's name? Newt Gingrich in work there. It was the republican program that Dick Morris convinced Clinton to sign as President because Congress had it in inset, and that what led to warfare, that was what led to a rise and lower in poverty in the black community and a rise by over 44 percent. So, let's stop assigning the false narratives and deal with the facts at hand.

GOODSTEIN: Bill Clinton was President, you will concede that, right?

WEBB: Yes, he was president, but it was a republican plan that he signed.

GOODSTEIN: Thank you.

BOLTON: All right.

GOODSTEIN: It wasn't a republican plan in '93 when Bill Clinton decided to raise taxes. All the republicans Dick Armey said we were going to have a big collapse and we had the biggest economic growth ever. That was on republican plan.

BOLTON: All right.

BARNES: But, Richard, the issue is Kaepernick, it's not Trump or Clinton, it's Kaepernick. And we'll see what happens to him. You know, David Stern, when he had a basketball player, Chris Jackson in the NBA, wouldn't stand.

BOLTON: Right.

BARNES: You know what he told Chris Jackson, he said, look, you don't have to stand, but you'll get fined every game you don't stand for the Star- Spangled Banner.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: Right. That's a good reminder.

BARNES: You know what happened? He started to stand.

BOLTON: Fred, Richard, and David, thank you. We're back in a minute.

BOLTON: Fox Business Network has special coverage of Donald Trump's immigration speech tomorrow starting at 7 p.m. Eastern Time.

In the meantime, my colleague Liz Macdonald here for Charles Payne. Making Money starts now.

value.Title: Clipping the wings of Big Tech will be a battle royal

After years of hoovering up colossal amounts of personal data, feasting on the barely contested M&A deals of rivals and bolstering their dominant market position in a dizzying assortment of businesses, they are now the biggest and wealthiest corporations on earth, wielding vast power and financial muscle. More important, they have no desire to be ...

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W8P-0T81-JCBW-N3XW-00000-00Clipping the wings of Big Tech will be a battle royal2019-06-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:52ZLexisNexisBUSINESS;NEWSPg. 2Clipping the wings of Big Tech will be a battle royalROBIN PAGNAMENTA

After years of slumber, US regulators woke up with a start this week to the antitrust threat posed by Big Tech.

In a brief statement issued late on Monday, the House judiciary committee sounded the alarm with the announcement that it was launching a "top-to-bottom review of the market power held by giant tech platforms".

For many in Europe, where the fight to defang Big Tech has been under way for years, the move feels overdue.

But as they rub their eyes, yawn and survey the competitive landscape before them, they shouldn't underestimate the challenges ahead.

Following 20 years of explosive growth in a near regulatory vacuum, the tech companies they now plan to scrutinise - Amazon, Facebook, Google et al - are the mightiest beasts in global business.

After years of hoovering up colossal amounts of personal data, feasting on the barely contested M&A deals of rivals and bolstering their dominant market position in a dizzying assortment of businesses, they are now the biggest and wealthiest corporations on earth, wielding vast power and financial muscle.

More important, they have no desire to be cut down to size or to acquiesce to the erection of anything more the flimsiest of regulatory guard rails.

Former Google chairman Eric Schmidt summed up Silicon Valley's attitude - and its likely litigious response - in an interview with The Daily Telegraph last month when he said he saw "no basis in law" for a break-up of any kind.

Facebook's top lobbyist Nick Clegg struck a similar tone recently. "You don't enforce accountability by calling for the break-up of a successful American company," he said.

Either way, with extraordinarily deep pockets and access to the finest and most handsomely paid lawyers and lobbyists on the planet, this is a tussle that could run and run.

If they are serious, then US lawmakers, the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission - which are limbering up now too - should be ready for a protracted and brutal contest.

Perhaps inevitably, comparisons have been drawn with the antitrust offensive against the Standard Oil empire of John D Rockefeller. But that took 21 years - starting in 1890 and culminating in 1911 - and it was arguably rather less complex.

Although Standard Oil encompassed an astonishing variety of businesses - from oil production to pipelines, railways, refineries and distribution companies - this was a business assembled by a single man in a single industry - and efforts to dismember it were largely restricted to its operations in one country: the US.

For regulators, Big Tech is a far more amorphous and diverse target, composed of a variety of truly global companies whose alleged ills are far more extensive.

This is not just a fight about predatory pricing or monopolistic behaviour by powerful companies over a single industry. Google and Facebook exercise a vice-like grip over the global online ad market, of course. But they are also accused of spreading misinformation, abusing the privacy of customers and of amplifying the views of extreme Right-wing or terror groups.

These are all different concerns to some of those about Amazon and Apple, for example - neither of which can really be described as a monopoly. Amazon may be a huge company but it still only controls a 5pc share of the US retail market. That is why regulators need to rapidly decide what they intend to focus on and what their priorities should be.

At the moment, the approach seems muddled, giving the impression of a thoughtless all-out assault on an industry that has brought many benefits to consumers as well as potential harm.

So far, however, US lawmakers have shown little sign of being up to the challenge. When Mark Zuckerberg explained patiently to a hearing last year that "Senator, we run ads", he offered a revealing glimpse of Silicon Valley's real view of Washington DC. The subtext was clear: "These ageing dopes really have no idea how our industry works." Nevertheless, the sense that Silicon Valley's biggest players are under siege - not just in Europe where Margrethe Vestager, the competition commissioner, has been levying big fines but now in the US too - is growing.

The US tech giants have traditionally shunned political lobbying - at least compared to other industries like pharmaceuticals or energy - but the industry is now tooling up for a fight.

Google, Amazon, and Facebook forked out record amounts to influence the US government in 2018. They spent a combined $48m (£38m) on lobbying - up 13pc from 2017. The largest increase came from Google, which lifted its lobbying spending 18pc to over $21m. Facebook's spending rose 10pc to over $12m.

With the threat of US antitrust action looming, you can bet those figures are destined to shoot up again sharply in 2019, not least because the tech industry is now feeling the heat from all sides of the political spectrum.

Democrats such as Elizabeth Warren, the long-standing antitrust campaigner who is now running for the nomination for president, is agitating for a break-up of Big Tech.

But Donald Trump also has the industry in his sights, driven by a dislike of Silicon Valley's arch-liberal values and claims that conservative views are suppressed on social media.

With political pressure building, fireworks can be expected. Just don't expect a resolution any time soon.

'Google, Amazon, and Facebook forked out record amounts to influence the US government in 2018'

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60BX-GD31-DYWJ-F0MK-00000-00Clive Waller: The latest scandal proves ESG isn't a fad2020-07-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:52ZLexisNexisClive Waller: The latest scandal proves ESG isn't a fadtom.ellis@incisivemedia.com(Tom Ellis)

Last week, Chuka Umunna was appointed to head up ESG consultancy at Edelman, the communications company.

Last week, Shell announced that it was cutting the value of its oil and gas reserves by $22 billion. A few weeks ago, BP cut the value of its assets by $17.5 billion. This is not just short-term reaction to the coronavirus crisis, but reaction to climate change and the need to cut global dependency on carbon based fuel.

Last week, The Sunday Times published its exposé of Boohoo, revealing both its below legal pay and appalling work conditions, increasing the risk of coronavirus infection. The share price has fallen 35%.

Last week, it was revealed that a major fund manager (Merian) was the second highest shareholder after the owner. The fund manager states that they were one of the first fund managers to understand the importance of ESG. This begs a question or two.

Last week, Motely Fool and Yahoo Finance suggested that Boohoo was now a good buy!

There are still those who believe ESG is merely a FAD, the current cool, maybe woke, trend that will disappear when we get back to normal. Not a chance.

ESG came about in 2004 when the UN Gobal Compact got together with the investment community. They devised PRI, principles for responsible investment, to achieve a more sustainable global financial future.

From the investor viewpoint, and the managers of $80 trillion who have signed up to PRI, the issue is one of risk. If you invest in a company that is forced to write down $billions of assets, the share price falls.

If you invest in a company that mistreats its employees (like Boohoo), the share price falls. If you invest in a company with great policies on recruitment and treatment of staff, shareholders, neighbours, product life cycle, and a great product, the chances are that you will receive a great return. In other words, it's about fear and greed.

The challenge for those promoting ESG investment is transparency and clarity. Why should you believe a manager who says his firm follows ESG principles unless you understand the basis of selection or exclusion of stocks and the source of the data employed?

Larger asset managers tend to use their own research, often in tandem with data providers such as Sustainalytics, MSCI or Refinitiv. That is not enough. We need to understand exactly how they do it. I have studied the process followed by Refintiv. I am not suggesting it is the right one to follow, but to its credit the process is fully disclosed and transparent.

The crucial message behind an ESG rating is to remember that it should not be judgemental. They may rate an oil company well because it is investing large amounts in non-carbon energy and behaves well in other respects. One analyst said to me: "Our role is to find best in class."

There are those investors who wish to make very specific choices about where they place their money. Some wish to invest in companies that they believe will create a better world, e.g. carbon alternatives or innovate medical products.

Others wish to exclude what they perceive as non-ethical products. This is the most controversial and subjective area. Some will exclude pharmaceuticals because some behave extremely badly - true. Yet, the awareness of the need for drug companies and research has never been clearer than now. Some regard alcohol as unethical, whereas others, like me, regard it as an absolute essential.

What about banks? Do any banks behave well? Yet we need banks.

Sadly, it gets more complex. While some see the big tech companies as great example and all that is good for the future, others see them as beyond the pale. Look to Volkswagen, which was one of the most highly regarded companies in Europe - until they were found to cheat their customers.

For me, there are two options.

The first is where investors direct their money, following their wishes and helped by their advisers. This could lead to ethical, impact, thematic and similar funds or portfolios. There are fund managers and DFMs that specialise in these products and do a great job.

The second option is to invest across the investment landscape but with a form of screening that removes companies that are behaving badly. I use the present tense quite deliberately, because things change. A good example might be a tracker.

As a passive investor, I do not want to try to pick stock that will outperform, or back stock pickers. However, I would like to exclude the Boohoos of this world. Thus, my ideal fund is a tracker with an ESG screen that removes all stocks with an ESG score below an agreed level.

So, to be, perhaps, controversial, I very much believe in arms companies. I don't want to live in a world where Putin or Xi, for example, can get their wishes because nothing will stop them. I want to invest in an arms business that does not sell AR15s to white supremacists or Al Qaeda terrorists.

I do not wish to invest in a pharma business that buys a patent so that it can jack up the prices tenfold because it can. Moreover, I want the manager to move money as companies change their behaviour for better or worse.

We will not change the world purely by directing our money at nice companies. Indeed, if we cheapen the stock price, we make it more attractive to those without principles. If all nice people sell an arms manufacturer, there are plenty of hedge funds, private equity houses and sovereign wealth funds that will be delighted to pick up the shares at a discount - see earlier comment re Boohoo.

ESG is about rewarding good corporate behaviour and penalising the bad. Hopefully it will lead to a better, nicer world and be a check on climate change.

Very finally, both legislation and regulation will make adherence by business, investment managers and advisers compulsory. It is not a fad.

Clive Waller is managing director at CWC Research

urn:contentItem:60W3-GDY1-F07F-82K9-00000-00Clock Ticks On TikTok, WeChat Bans – And eCommerce May Suffer2020-09-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:52ZLexisNexisNEWSClock Ticks On TikTok, WeChat Bans – And eCommerce May Suffer

Sunday looms as a red-letter day for TikTok and Tencent’s WeChat – and tens of millions of users who use the apps to conduct commerce. Here in the States, the government is restricting access to the two apps in a battle between China and the U.S. that cent... Sunday looms as a red-letter day for TikTok and...

Sunday looms as a red-letter day for TikTok and Tencent’s WeChat – and tens of millions of users who use the apps to conduct commerce. Here in the States, the government is restricting access to the two apps in a battle between China and the U.S. that cent...

Sunday looms as a red-letter day for TikTok and Tencent’s WeChat – and tens of millions of users who use the apps to conduct commerce. Here in the States, the government is restricting access to the two apps in a battle between China and the U.S. that centers on national security. The Commerce Department said on Friday (Sept. 18) that providers will be banned from distributing those apps, which of course impacts Google and Apple, the tech giants whose app stores are key access areas. "The only real change as of Sunday night will be [TikTok users] won't have access to improved apps, updated apps, upgraded apps or maintenance," Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross said on Friday morning, as reported by The New York Times . Drilling down into what a ban actually means, in terms of using the apps themselves, the Commerce Department order states in stark terms that “any transaction by any person, or with respect to any property, subject to the jurisdiction of the United States, with ByteDance Ltd …shall be prohibited to the extent permitted under applicable law.” The ban cites the May 15, 2019 executive order signed by President Donald Trump (known as Executive Order 13873) contending that foreign adversaries are “increasingly creating and exploiting vulnerabilities in information and communications technology and services (ICTS)” to obtain sensitive information. The Friday announcement is the latest chapter in an ongoing saga between ByteDance and companies such as Microsoft and Oracle, which are in talks to create a U.S.-based firm that would, ostensibly, allay those data security concerns. Beyond the geopolitical saber-rattling, here’s what it all means: The Trump administration’s ban would restrict Apple and Google from letting users in the U.S. utilize those apps, while still letting users outside the U.S. use them. That demarcation, we contend, divides the world into users who can transact and those who cannot, and has ripple effects for eCommerce. As of Sept. 20 for TikTok and Nov. 12 for WeChat, the Commerce Department is banning updates to the codes, the transmission of data and, as the order notes, “any provision of internet hosting” or “content delivery network services enabling the functioning or optimization of the mobile application” in the US. The order seems a way to basically render the apps nonexistent in the U.S. Interestingly, the order specifically states that the prohibition does not apply to TikTok’s “payment of wages, salaries and benefit packages to employees or contractors.” A separate release by the Commerce Department noted that as of Sunday, prohibited transactions include “any provision of services through the WeChat mobile application for the purpose of transferring funds or processing payments within the U.S.” As widely reported, TikTok’s user base in the U.S. is around 100 million; WeChat’s installed base here is 19 million, as Reuters reported . In terms of commerce, the impact on the apps’ parent companies may be slight. As reported in The Wall Street Journal, Tencent garners less than 2 percent of its sales from the U.S. But the bans would quickly hobble commerce conducted by Chinese nationals living, working and studying here – and, of course, making payments here. And TikTok has caught on like wildfire in the States, especially among younger users. And as PYMNTS reported last month , as bans first loomed: There is the specter of an economic war of sorts conducted across borders (here, between China and the U.S.) that could ensnare Big Tech. Apple gets a mid-teens percentage revenue contribution from the country; the card giants have been trying to gain a foothold in China. If the U.S. bans hosting and transmission, as well as mobile conduits, the quarrel will quickly escalate, ensnaring merchants, payments processors and, of course, consumers. It was unclear last month what scope of transactions the Trump administration would look to curtail – and now the scope has crystallized. The ban’s extent is broad indeed – and what’s left undefined, at least for now, is just how widespread the impact may be to eCommerce as a result of trade tensions. —————————— LIVE PYMNTS TV OCTOBER SERIES: POWERING THE DIGITAL SHIFT – B2B PAYMENTS 2021 Banks, corporates and even regulators now recognize the imperative to modernize — not just digitize —the infrastructures and workflows that move money and data between businesses domestically and cross-border. Together with Visa, PYMNTS invites you to a month-long series of livestreamed programs on these issues as they reshape B2B payments. Masters of modernization share insights and answer questions during a mix of intimate fireside chats and vibrant virtual roundtables. Recommended for you

PRODS@WEBLOGSINC.COM (Jon Ogg)

Apr. 22, 2010 (AOL Weblogs delivered by Newstex) --
March PPI rose 0.7%, but core prices rose only 0.1%. The annual rate of inflation fell marginally to 0.9% in March versus 1.0% in February. That was much higher a year ago. Today's news gave the Fed a reason to stand pat on no rate hikes. The other good news is those pesky jobless claims showed the first drop in 3 weeks by 24,000 down to 456,000. Even the continuing claims (the long-lived army of the unemployed) fell 40,000 to 4,646,000.


And despite more calls for more regulation from the Obama administration, stocks staged a much better close than they indicated this morning before the open, even if the Black-Red verdict was not evident until the final minutes of the day.
Here were today's closing bell levels:
Dow 11,134.29 +9.37 (0.08%)
S&P 500 1,208.67 +2.74 (0.23%)
Nasdaq 2,519.07 +14.46 (0.58%)
Top Day Trader Alerts
Apple, Inc.(   AAPL) had another solid day with yet another all-time high, which may in part be due to a   technical analyst call from last night calling for much higher prices. Apple's new high is $266.75 but it was up 2.3% at $265.17 late in the trading day.
QUALCOMM Inc. (   QCOM) was the big tech earnings disappointment. Guidance was higher but the metrics were not pleasing. This was down 8.5% at $39.01 shortly before the close.
eBay Inc.(   EBAY) is proof that monopolies aren't always a win. Earnings barely beat estimates last night and the guidance was soft to in-line at best. Shares were down 6.3% at $24.62 shortly before the close, but that was at least better than the $23.90 seen this morning when the market was still weak.
Starbucks, Inc. (   SBUX) is the turnaround that is now back on its feet and firing on most cylinders. It beat earnings, raised guidance, and saw margin expansion from its cost cuts and from its reorganization. Shares were up 7.6% at $27.32 shortly before the close; its new 52-week high from this afternoon is $27.45.
Qwest Communications (   Q) is being acquired by CenturyTel (NYSE:CTL) (   CTL), yet the stock hardly budged as it is a stock deal where CenturyTel will hold 50.5% of the combined NewCo after its merger is completed next year. Qwest was up 2.5% at $5.37 late in the day, while CenturyTel was down 3.5% at $34.94 late in the day.
Netflix, Inc. (   NFLX) blew past estimates and added 1.7 million subscribers. Not bad, well, great! Shares were up a sharp 15% at $100.30 on active volume trading shortly before the close.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60GW-0931-F11P-X0Y0-00000-00Closing digital divide: Tech titans at bay?2020-08-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:52ZLexisNexisClosing digital divide: Tech titans at bay?

By Diane Coyle/Cambridge

Big Tech is back in the spotlight – and not in a good way. On July 29, the chief executives of Amazon, Apple, Google, and Facebook spent more than five hours fielding tough questions about their overwhelming market power from a bipartisan antitrust panel in the US House of Representatives. Is the end of an era approaching?


In many ways, the Covid-19 pandemic has been a boon for tech companies. As Amazon's Jeff Bezos, Apple's Tim Cook, Google's Sundar Pichai, and Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg all noted in their opening statements at the antitrust hearing, people appreciate the services their companies provide. Recent research indicates that the Covid-19 crisis has deepened this appreciation.
This is not surprising. Digital technologies have enabled workers to do their jobs from home, students to continue their classes while schools are closed, and people to stay in touch with loved ones and entertain themselves while sheltering in place.
Tech companies have been reaping enormous benefits from this shift. In the first half of 2020, while the global economy confronted an unprecedented recession, Amazon's share price rose by about 40%, fuelled by rising online purchases and increased used of cloud services. Zoom's market value has more than tripled since the start of the Covid-19 crisis, as it became a hub for remote meetings and online socialising.
As for Google and Facebook, they suffered temporary losses from reduced advertising revenues. But they still account for an overwhelming share of the digital-advertising market – four-fifths in the United Kingdom, to cite one example. Moreover, while Google and Facebook are free to use, the UK Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has concluded that consumers are effectively paying for their services indirectly through advertising revenues, at a rate of £500 ($656) per household annually – a testament to their market power.
It is too early to say how much of people's lives will move online, or for how long. People may fear Covid-19, but they also suffer from Zoom fatigue. Nonetheless, it seems likely that work and social patterns will undergo some sustained changes, which will have far-reaching policy implications.
For starters, closing the digital divide will become more urgent than ever. Of the many forms of inequality the pandemic is exposing and exacerbating, unequal access to the Internet and digital technologies is among the most prominent.
All the services that have made lives so much better under social-distancing rules – from remote working to online shopping to streaming services – are available only to those with access to a reasonably fast and reliable Internet connection and suitable hardware. Many are also receiving healthcare and accessing government support online, further highlighting the critical importance of universal access.
In recent years, governments have increasingly recognised this imperative. For example, in 2018, the US Federal Communications Commission made closing the digital divide a high priority. And yet about one in 20 people in the United States still have no high-speed Internet connection. In rural areas, about one-third of households are not connected. The figures are similarly bleak in the UK.
Closing the gap will require large-scale investment in digital infrastructure, including broadband connectivity and 5G for mobile services. In both the US and the UK, governments are working to deliver on the first imperative, by making the low-return rural investments that cannot attract private capital. Progress on the second imperative may be more difficult, owing to political opposition to the Chinese telecoms giant and 5G leader Huawei.
But Huawei may be turn out to be the tip of an iceberg, because the current shift online will lead to greater political and regulatory scrutiny of tech giants. For one thing, regulators are likely to pressure telecommunications companies to increase investment, spurring debates about license obligations and pricing (how much companies must invest, and how they will fund it). Past disputes about where along the value chain costs should fall – from physical network operators to streaming services – may re-emerge.
But, as the recent US antitrust hearing suggests, the most contentious issue will probably be the market power of digital companies. Even in today's highly polarised political environment, growing concern about Big Tech – including the viability of small producers and the economy's dependence on digital market access – is broadly shared. And US regulators have already signalled their concern, with inquiries by both the Federal Trade Commission and the Department of Justice.
The European Union is far ahead of the US when it comes to regulating, taxing, and constraining Big Tech. The European Commission has pursued multiple antitrust cases against the tech giants, as well as broader initiatives such as the proposed Digital Services Act. Margrethe Vestager – previously the European commissioner for competition, and currently Executive Vice President of the European Commission for A Europe Fit for the Digital Age – has led the way on this front.
In the UK, the CMA is working to implement the Furman Review, a government-commissioned report on digital-market competition published in March 2019. The panel recommended subjecting strategically important companies to targeted regulation, including a code of conduct that will likely cover issues such as favouring one's own services, changes in terms and conditions, and pre-notification of all mergers.
It remains to be seen how such efforts will play out, especially in a US headed toward a highly contentious presidential election. But one thing is clear: Though the tech monopolists may capture significant short-term gains from the accelerating shift online, they can no longer avoid the harsh glare of the political spotlight. The writing may be on the wall. – Project Syndicate

* Diane Coyle, Professor of Public Policy at the University of Cambridge, is the author, most recently, of Markets, State, and People: Economics for Public Policy (Princeton University Press, 2020).

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W17-VSF1-F11P-X3R9-00000-00Closing Europe's confidence gap2019-04-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:52ZLexisNexisClosing Europe's confidence gapAna Palacio

In Spanish, the word confianza has a double meaning. On one hand, it describes a firm trust in something or someone the kind of trust that people around the world, from Brazil to the United States to North Africa, increasingly lack in their leaders and even governance systems. On the other hand, confianza refers to confidence in oneself something that is in particularly short supply in Europe.

In fact, the European Union is suffering from a deficit of confianza in both senses. This is a uniquely dangerous mix, because a lack of trust and self-confidence is leading the EU not just to outsider politics and even outlaw politicians, but also to policy paralysis, public outrage and an utter inability to determine its own destiny. Both before and after next month's European Parliament election, which will precede a new European Commission and a new European Council president this deficit must urgently be addressed.

Public trust in EU leaders and institutions took a serious hit after the 2008 financial crisis. By then, the original purpose of the European project to support peace on the continent after the devastation of World War II had lost its purchase on public opinion. Europeans had gotten used to peace.

Meanwhile, "Europe" became focused on the broader and vaguer goal of championing "shared values." That objective underpinned the establishment of the formal EU institutions.

For voters, however, lofty ideals were not the point. Europe had achieved peace through prosperity; mutually beneficial economic relations were the key to deterring conflict. But, as the memory of the war faded, the means became the ends. Prosperity was all that mattered.

So, when markets crashed in 2008, and Europe was engulfed by a series of crises (which were exacerbated by flaws in the European architecture), the public lost confidence that the European project was even viable, let alone desirable. These doubts intensified as other trends including globalization, automation and the emerging dominance of Big Tech transformed economies and societies, creating new sources of insecurity.

Economies had become much broader than societies, and thus lacked the social underpinnings of the past. Add to that the expansion of the regulatory state, and citizens felt a perceptible loss of agency.

The resulting uncertainty has produced fear and frustration, fueling popular anger not just at flaws in the system, but also at the system itself and the "elites" who had "imposed" it. Aided by opportunistic politicians, mainstream political parties have become the enemy, and experts have lost credibility. Truth itself is under attack.

An effective response to this challenge must be broad, multilayered, and robust. In European countries and in the Western democracies more broadly such a response requires political leaders to engage more deeply with citizens, together with efforts to build societal resilience. At the European level, it also demands the development of a clear raison d'être that extends beyond prosperity.

But it also means the construction of a more effective, results-oriented institutional arrangement.

The EU has been an intergovernmental, rather than a transnational, endeavor since at least the financial crisis. Agenda-setting and decision-making authority lies with national governments, and, by default, powerful members, especially Germany, and disruptive mavericks, such as Hungary and Poland, dominate these processes.

During the financial crisis, Europeans looked to German Chancellor Angela Merkel, not then-European Commission President Jose Manuel Barroso, for a solution. Despite the declaration by Barroso's successor, Jean-Claude Juncker, that his commission represented a "last chance" for winning back the support of citizens, Merkel has also dominated decision-making these last five years. This is exemplified by migration, where time and again decisions impacting the EU as a whole, including the bloc's agreement with Turkey, were taken in Berlin with little or no consultation. This is the reality.

And yet the European Parliament and the commission have sought to increase their own powers.

This is the wrong way to achieve a meaningfully central place in policymaking. Instead of attempting to offset the power of member states by expanding their competencies, these institutions should focus on comparative advantage.

For the European Parliament, this could mean establishing itself as a source of facts, ideas, and vision, rather than as a co-legislator, given how little appetite there is for surrendering sovereignty even over the most practical issues. At a time of disinformation and confusion, the Parliament could conduct credible studies and disseminate authoritative research, much like the House of Lords does in the United Kingdom.

For the European Commission, the goal should be to strengthen its role as protector of the spirit and vision of the EU treaties, while taking responsibility for proper policy implementation. This would require the commission to stop trying to show at every opportunity that it is the captain of the ship. As these last years have shown, without political buy-in, it cannot follow through on any course it charts, whether on migration, energy independence, or defense. This failure undermines the EU's credibility, while wasting time and resources.

As for the European Council, it must act more as a collegium and less a loudspeaker for the views of certain capitals in setting direction. Here the role and personality of the council's incoming president, who will set the tone, is crucial.

By focusing on rebuilding confianza in both its forms, the next commission, Parliament and council can bolster the EU's legitimacy and facilitate progress in core areas, such as consolidating the euro and completing the single market and banking union. This new, stronger EU would be far better equipped to defend European interests and values on the world stage, which would bolster public trust further.

But if the EU institutions fail to show the needed humility and vision, no such virtuous circle will emerge. The European ship could continue to drift along aimlessly; worse, it will take on water until, ultimately, it sinks. In the stormy seas of escalating great power competition, that will happen more quickly than EU leaders seem to recognize.

Ana Palacio is former Minister of Foreign Affairs of Spain and former Senior Vice President and General Counsel of the World Bank Group. She is a visiting lecturer at Georgetown University.
